title: UCS Tie-breaker ordering (for updated nodes)
author: Chloe Good (anon. to classmates)
text:
I have a question about how to order updated nodes on our open queue in the following situation:
  Our queue starts out like:
...
A (cost = 5,   nodeID = 7)
B (cost = 6,   nodeID = 3)  -----> i.e. it has been on this queue longer than A
...
  Now we add children of current node in the order they were given in input.txt.
Let's say the children were given in order: C (cost = 5-x, nodeID = 9), D (cost = 5-x, nodeID = 10).
  First we add the new item to the queue:    C (cost = 5, nodeID = 9) 
So we now have:
...
A (cost = 5,   nodeID = 7)
C (cost = 5,  nodeID = 9)
B (cost = 6,   nodeID = 3)  -----> i.e. it has been on this queue longer than A
...
  Next we look at the next child: D(cost = 5, nodeID = 10)
I know that we will want to update our node with this lower cost and update the parent; however, do we also treat this as a new node? That is, which of the following ordering is correct?
  1)  Update only parent and cost but keep original nodeID. This means it will now go before A because it has been on the queue longer.
...
B (cost = 5,   nodeID = 3)  -----> i.e. it has been on this queue longer than A
A (cost = 5,   nodeID = 7)
C (cost = 5,  nodeID = 9)
...
  2) Update cost and parent, but do not place updated node before other nodes already on the queue that have that same cost. This would probably require some sort of extra tie-breaking condition involving nodeID and discovered status
...
A (cost = 5,   nodeID = 7)
B (cost = 5,   nodeID = 3) ??
C (cost = 5,  nodeID = 9)
...
  3) Update parent, cost, and nodeID (i.e. treat it as an entirely new node .... i believe this case has already been determined wrong based on the "hints" notes the professor provided for the class)
...
A (cost = 5,   nodeID = 7)
C (cost = 5,  nodeID = 9)
B (cost = 5,   nodeID = 10)
...
    I believe others have posted this same question, but I have not seen a definitive response on how to deal with such a situation.

followup.name: Chloe Good (anon. to classmates)
followup.text:
The question was not intended to be a "solve my test case" question. Rather, it is a request for further clarification regarding how to correctly insert/reorder new and updated elements into the openQ. I understand that completely new, undiscovered nodes go at the end if they are the same cost as nodes already on the queue.
  However, for discovered nodes on the openQ that now have an updated cost, are they reinserted into the queue in order of increasing age (i.e. the longer the element has been on the list, the sooner it will be explored) or does the discovered node that already has this cost get explored before the updated one ?

replies.name: Daniel Link
replies.text: I'm going to translate "openQ" to "open queue" because not everybody may immediately understand the term. For UCS and A*, you'll want a priority queue for your open queue. A priority queue self-sorts based on whatever you make the priority criterion. Depending on which programming language you use for your implementation, that language may have that structure built in or you may have to implement it yourself. Depending on the details of the implementation, If you update a member of the queue, you may have to remove and reinsert it so the queue can order itself again.

title: type of search in continuous space?
author: Shashank Shekhar
text:
Hi,
  I have a question regarding the search that we have discussed till now. These search (DFS, BFS, A*, etc) are for discrete space and which means, we go to one state and then look for the next step to take and reach the next state (like chess or cities as nodes). What about a continuous environment, what kind of search we can use?

author: Sriram
student_answer.text:
Extending the instructor's answer we can do it by creating ranges for the input values. One way to discretize it is by using range of the values.
  for instance,
In discrete case:
A->B cost:15
  may be converted to
A->B if f(x) > 10 and f(x) < 20 , where f(x) is you continuous cost function.

title: UCS Tie-breaker generalized question
author: Daniel Link
text:
In the UCS tie-breaker, if a node that has been in the queue for a long time (to make it easier, say it's been there since the start) gets updated to have a lower cost, does it...
  A) Get treated like a new node and put at the end of all nodes with the same cost.
B) Get treated like it's been in the queue for a long time and get placed before the other nodes with the same cost
("if all else is still equal, newly expanded nodes should be enqueued after (farther in the queue from the queue's front) older ones that were already in the queue." this rule makes A and B possible)
C) Regardless of original enqueing order, queue it up in regards to what order it is in the live-traffic input
(“If all else is equal while searching routes (ties), you should explore (enqueue) multiple paths from the same intersection in the order in which they are listed in the live traffic inputs." this rule makes C possible)
  I've seen this question posted multiple times, seen different answers, and am now confused.
  Thanks for any and all help.
  Note: There is no example in the hw hints about a scenario where an already enqueued node gets its value changed down to a lower value.
  Edit: I think that answer A or B is actually the most likely from instructor Daniel Link's mention of a priority queue, since in a priority queue you would have one particular way of ordering things (time of enqueue in this case) while in choice C you would have to account for both time of enqueue AND the live traffic input ranking, which would mean you can't use a priority queue and would have to have different scenarios (inserting a node vs changing a node) and comparisons (sometimes based on live traffic, sometimes based on time of enqueue).

author: Connor Zarecki
student_answer.text: With the choices you gave, I think the closest would be C. It would be behind nodes that are lower cost as well as nodes that are the same cost but appear earlier in the live-traffic input. It is ahead of nodes that are higher cost as well as nodes that are the same cost but appear later in the live-traffic input.

followup.name: Wayne Chi (anon. to classmates)
followup.text: Thanks to Connor for attempting to answer my question. However, I have read on multiple other threads that it is actually choice number B (even though I actually coded it as C myself) so I would really like a definitive answer from a TA or instructor.

replies.name: Connor Zarecki
replies.text: No problem, we'll have to wait to see what they say.

replies.name: Xiaokang Sun (anon. to classmates)
replies.text: I have the same question. Hi, TAs, please answer this question, don't ask us another question without answer this one plz plz, because no enough time left and here're a lot of confusion.

replies.name: Daniel Link
replies.text:
I'm sorry but we're very much held to not giving too many direct replies. I feel that the "clean, robust algorithm" shows you what you need to be doing. I also feel that the phrasing of the question is a little bit loaded, meaning there are terms in there that don't apply and make what could be clear choices confusing.
  One thing is that there's no notion of "time" in a priority queue. I'm also not seeing a clear difference between A and C considering the operation that's necessary in the "clean, robust algorithm" is on a single node.
  There's the issue that it doesn't matter so much whether a node gets treated like a new one, it just matters what you do with it and where it ends up. I feel that shouldn't be an issue with a properly written priority queue.

replies.name: Chloe Good (anon. to classmates)
replies.text:
I think the confusion is with the added tie-breaker rule: “if all else is still equal, newly expanded nodes should be enqueued after (farther in the queue from the queue's front) older ones that were already in the queue.”
  If I am correct, we are confusing nodes and states? That is, we are confusing state "age" (i.e. how long a particular state has been on the queue) vs node "age" (nodes contain path cost/parent/state relationships). So that is why choice B is wrong. Is that correct?

followup.name: Jichao Zhong
followup.text:
1. D is enqueued before B
(front) A(4)  B(6) C(8)  D(10)
at a certain step, cost of D was updated to 6, now there is a tie. 
(front) A(4)  B(6) D(6)  C(8)
D should be in front of C but not B, even though B was enqueued after D, 
since B reached cost 6 earlier than D.
So I think B should be in the front of D. Live traffic inputs should not be considered.
  2. X and Y have the same parent
      S
  5/    \5
 X       Y
For this scenario, S has the same cost to X and Y.
At this time, live inputs should be considered to decide which node should be enqueued first.
  The difference is:
B and D have been in the queue when the tie happens. When the tie happens, what you do is to update the queue rather than enqueue them again.
X and Y have not been enqueued when there is a tie. Live inputs will be considered to decide which one is first.
  That is my understanding.
Waiting for official clarification.

replies.name: Wayne Chi (anon. to classmates)
replies.text:
So you think the answer is choice A. I'm not saying you're right or wrong, but as you can see in Connor's answer that there is definitely confusion about this.
  Thanks for contributing!

replies.name: Wayne Chi (anon. to classmates)
replies.text:
So you're answer is choice A. Whether or not this is right, Connor's answer was choice C, showing some confusion about how tie-breakers are done.
  I also agree with your answer choice as a possible solution, (and it wouldn't be that hard of a fix) so I would really like an instructor to clarify.
  Thanks for contributing.

replies.name: Sebastian Gomez Velasco
replies.text:
Well, I agree with choice A.
  One instructor previously replied on this post " I feel that the 'clean, robust algorithm' shows you what you need to be doing".

The algorithm on slide 113 (session 2-4) says that if a node exists in the open queue with the same state as the child node, and the cost of the new child node is lower that the existing node, then:
1. Delete the node with the same state from the open queue.
2. Add the new child node to the open queue.
  Therefore, I think it should be treated as a new node (choice A).
  It does not say anything about updating the node in the queue.

replies.name: Haejun Lee
replies.text: I believe what Sebastian says is right since we are instructed to follow the pseudo code in lecture slides, and also professor told in the lecture to use the "clean and robust algorithm." In that case, we'll delete node and make a new one in either case of in the queue or explored.

title: A* re-discovering or not nodes in the closed list
author: Sebastian Gomez Velasco (anon. to classmates)
text:
I've been reading some posts on Piazza asking whether or not (in the realm of HW1) we should add to the open queue a node that IS in the closed list and for which we have found a cheaper path.
  In @114, Daniel Link has stated that: We should use the standard implementation that can be found on Wikipedia or similar sites, because there is no pseudo-code on the slides for A*.
  The problem is that Wikipedia's version of A* assumes a consistent heuristic, and states (in additional notes) that if the heuristic is not consistent, nodes in the closed may be rediscovered and their cost improved (modifying the pseudo code).
  For this, the last answer was that both versions will work.
So, I would like to share this input for A*.
  A*
S
G
7
S A 1
S B 4
A B 2
A C 5
A G 12
B C 2
C G 3
5
S 7
A 6
B 2
C 1
G 0
  When we expand S, we add A and B to the open queue.
B (f = 4 + 2)
A (f = 1 + 6)
  Since B has a lower f, it gets expanded first, and the open queue has:
A (f = 1 + 6)
C (f = 6 + 1)
  Now, A has a lower f, so it gets expanded, and we find a cheaper path to B that is already in the closed.
  To sum up, if we implement A* as defined in Wikipedia (assuming a consistent heuristic), the answer would be:
S(0) -> B(4) -> C(6) -> G(9)
  However, if we implement A* as UCS is described on the slides (a modified version for A*), the answer would be:
S(0) -> A (1) -> B(3) -> C(5) -> G(8)
(that's reaching B from the cheaper path through A)
  Since it was stated that both versions of A* will work, does it mean that:
1. for these cases both solutions will be accepted as correct?
2. no case like this will be tested when grading? Meaning, there will NOT be the case that we find a cheaper path to a node that is already in the closed list.

followup.name: Nguyen (Chris) Tran (anon. to classmates)
followup.text:
This is a very interesting example.
  In the situation where we have a tie E(5), F(5), when we add D(5) into the queue after we explore node H, should D stay in the front of the queue since it appears before node E and F in the list?
    Thanks

replies.name: Sebastian Gomez Velasco
replies.text:
According to my understanding, the answer is: ACEG
  It's true that you'll have a tie between E, F and D; all with a cost of 5 so far, but applying the tie-breaking rules you get:
  1. E and F have the same parent, so you use the order in which they appear in the input file (E comes first)
2. D got removed from the open queue when it had cost of 6, and inserted again with a new cost of 5 (following the algorithm as specified on the slides), applying the last tie-breaking rule added in the hint section: newly expanded nodes should enqueued after older ones already in the queue, D goes last, after E and F.
  Therefore, the next node to expand is E, setting the path to the goal: ACEG

replies.name: Xuechao
replies.text: agree

followup.name: Garrett Witowski
followup.text: The answer is AHDG since D has been in the queue longer.

replies.name: Garrett Witowski
replies.text: Why did you link to that?

replies.name: Qingfeng Du
replies.text: According to "a clean robust algorithm" we should delete the original node and add the new node. So D is after E and F.

replies.name: Chai Zheng Xin
replies.text: You should delete old nodes only if the new node has shorter path length.

title: DFS/BFS - Checking Child Nodes for Goal before adding to Frontier
author: Timothy Wade
text: The reference Algorithm in our textbook for BFS (and by extension, DFS) indicates the correct implementation is to check the child nodes for the goal state, before adding it to the frontier, and return them if they are the goal.  I seem to recall that Professor Itti advised against getting in the habit of checking the goal state of children nodes as while it doesn't influence BFS/DFS, it may disrupt other searches (UCS, for example) -- I just wanted to confirm implementing the textbook's reference algorithm will be adequate and there aren't some hidden edge case where that reference implementation differs from an implementation that never checks children, only checks during exploration.

title: UCS Tiebreaker
author: Wayne Chi (anon. to classmates)
text:
Two rules conflict for UCS:
  Rule 1:
  "we do not enqueue a node [...] again since we already have one with lower cost in the open queue (loop detection)." - Slide 19 Hw #1 hints
  conflicts with
  Rule 2:
"else if there exists node in open that has child’s state
     if PathCost(child) < PathCost(node)
         open Delete-Node(open, node)
         open Queuing-Fn(open, child)
" - Slide 113 session 02-04 (aka the Clean, Robust, Algorithm)
  If there is a node already in the open queue, should we treat it like a new node as shown in Rule 2, or should we leave it, update its cost, and treat is as an old node as in Rule 1.
  This is important because of this following rule.
Rule 3:
"if all else is still equal, newly expanded nodes should be enqueued after (farther in the queue from the queue's front) older ones that were already in the queue" - Slide 27 HW #1 hints
  Depending on Rule 1 or Rule 2, a node that gets its cost updated may have a higher or lower priority among nodes of the same updated cost.
  Thanks for clarifying.

author: Daniel Link
Sriram
student_answer.text:
In general in abstract priority queue you have a natural ordering, i.e. any two keys that have the same priority are arranged in the order of their arrival.
For a simple PQ example (not an HW1 example!!), Order of insert
A - 3 (priority)
B - 5
D - 5
C - 5
E - 7
  higher priority better for us. so A will be at the end
The queue should always look like E, B, D, C, A after inserting A (When C is inserted, it is done far away from the queue's front, behind the other keys with same priority).
Now standard implementations in various languages have their own way to managing keys with same priority. For instance, java manages it arbitrarily. May be this is what they mean by Rule 3 and we should take care of this I guess. Also, there is no conflict between Rule 1 and 2.

followup.name: Wayne Chi (anon. to classmates)
followup.text: They conflict because if a node is already enqueued and the cost of it changes, do we not enqueue it again (Rule 1) or do we delete it and enqueue it again (Rule 2). This completely changes the queue time of the node, which will affect the order it appears in the priority queue.

replies.name: Steven Ly
replies.text: It depends on whether or not the cost of the child's node is less than the cost of a node in the existing queues. Rule 1 applies to the situation in which it isn't, so we don't enqueue the node. Rule 2 applies to the situation in which the cost is less, so we delete the node and enqueue the new node with less cost.

replies.name: Daniel Link
replies.text: I agree with the post above mine.

replies.name: Chloe Good (anon. to classmates)
replies.text:
I think the confusion is with Rule 3: “if all else is still equal, newly expanded nodes should be enqueued after (farther in the queue from the queue's front) older ones that were already in the queue.”
  If I am correct, I believe we are confusing nodes and states. That is, we are confusing state "age" (i.e. how long a particular state has been on the queue) vs node "age" (where each node has its determined path cost/parent/state relationship).
  So for Rule 2, the reason we delete the existing node and add the new one (with the same state) is because we have found a better, less costly path to this state, one via a different parent and with lesser cost (hence, an entirely new node). We do not care how long a given state has been on the queue. Is that correct?

replies.name: Chloe Good (anon. to classmates)
replies.text: To add to the above comment, this clarification is for the situation when a discovered node on the queue gets updated with a path cost that is equivalent to another discovered node on the queue. Whether a given state has already been on the queue before is irrelevant to ordering.

title: Clarification Needed
author: Garrett Witowski
text:
I believe some clarification is needed here... First of all, we know that UCS is nothing more than A* with 
h(n)=0
. So, if we implement UCS as A* and exclude 
h(n)
we could get a different answer than the "Clean, robust algorithm" that's described in the lecture slides, since A* performs a PQ-update not a PQ-delete followed by a PQ-insert. Consequentially, this results in the tiebreaking rules being applied differently. To illustrate, consider the example provided in @164:
  output of UCS ("clean, robust" version):
A 0
C 2
E 5
G 6
  output of UCS (A* version):
A 0
H 3
D 5
G 6
  Which of these would be considered the correct output for UCS, the "clean robust" one or the A* one?

author: Sebastian Gomez Velasco
student_answer.text:
Agree, but it actually raises the question: which is the correct version for A*? rather than which output is correct for UCS? (since UCS pseudo-code is on the slides)
  So basically, which version is the correct one for A*?
* A version based on UCS? (deleting and inserting nodes)?
* A version that updates the node in the queue?

title: (More) Clarification Needed
author: Garrett Witowski
text: We got some clarification in @177 on which version of UCS to implement, but someone else raised another good question: which version of A* do we use? One built from the "clean robust algorithm" or one that's built from Wikipedia's pseudo-code?

author: Garrett Witowski
Sebastian Gomez Velasco
student_answer.text:
To elaborate a little more the question. Which version is correct for A*?

* A version based on UCS? (deleting and inserting nodes)?
* A version that updates the existing node rather than creating a new one? (Wikipedia's version, taking into account that Wikipedia's pseudo-code does not use a queue)
  The answer to this question affects how we break ties using the last rule added last week.
    -------
Actually, Wikipedia's version does use a queue, they just don't explicitly mention it as being a queue.

followup.name: Garrett Witowski
followup.text: Perhaps you guys (the instructors) could pin a note with these updates so that we can avoid having duplicate questions?

followup.name: Sebastian Gomez Velasco
followup.text:
Thanks, but @114 refers to whether or not re-discover nodes that are already in the closed list when we find a cheaper path.
  Here we are asking for the open queue when we find a cheaper path to a node that has not been expanded yet. The question is for A* (for which we don't have the pseudo-code on the slides):
  * Do we remove (the expensive node) and create a new node (the cheap one) to be added to the open queue? (Based on UCS)
* Do we update the node in the queue? (More like Wikipedia's pseudo-code)
  Again, this affects tie-breaking.
  Therefore, it's not a duplicate question.

replies.name: Garrett Witowski
replies.text: Check out @179

title: Warning
author: Harshith Guru Prasad (anon. to classmates)
text:
When i submit the code on Vocareum I'm getting the following message
  Submitted with warning. 
skipped .viminfo -- permission denied.
  But my program still runs and 5 test cases are evaluated.
  Should this be a concern ?

author: Sriram
student_answer.text:
This shouldn't be an issue while submitting the code. Not to worry.
  But here is the reason this is happening. You would have used vi editor to edit your code through the terminal. .viminfo is created then, which typically stores the meta info for the edit. It is a hidden file. use "ls -a" to view the hidden files.
  To Fix: use "rm .viminfo" to delete that file and try submitting again.
  May be this is why they asked us not to debug in Vocareum! :-D Just saying!

The result may be like this sequence because the DFS implemented by stack and followed the order in which they are listed in the live traffic inputs.
  Fronier list: A
    Expand A: {B:1} {C:1}
    Add child:    B   C     (parent A)
Fronier list:      B    C

     Add child :  D           (parent B)
Fronier list:      D    C    
      Expand D: {E:3}
      Add child : E  (parent D)
Fronier list:      E    C

A 0
B 1
D 2
E 3

title: Confusion regarding implementation of UCS and A*
author: Akshay Deshmukh (anon. to classmates)
text:
I have been reading through threads about the implementations of UCS and A* and I am confused about the version of the algorithm to be used for implementation. Currently, there are two versions of UCS and A*:
  1. The version which updates a node in the Closed set if the child/current node (the node which has been recently dequeued from the Open set for the next pass of UCS/A*) has a cost (f(n)) lower than the node in the Closed set when the current node and the node in the Closed set are equal. This implementation has been given in slide 113 in session02-04.pptx (Clean Robust Algorithm for UCS). This kind of implementation was also demonstrated by Prof. Tejada in one of the lectures for A*.
The graph given above is a reference to the first version of implementation which encounters the given procedure for A*.
  2. In this version, UCS and A* does not check nodes which have been enqueued in the closed set. Once that node is in the closed set, irrespective of the fact that the current node (which is equal to a node in the closed set) may have a lower cost, it is never accessed. This is the standard implementation of UCS/A* which has been given in Wikipedia.
  Which version of UCS/A* is followed in the grading script? I request you to give a definite answer as the grading scheme is harsh.

author: Sriram
student_answer.text: @179. This answer was given by the TA.

title: Doubt in Clean-Robust Algorithm for Uniform Cost search and A*
author: Pankaj Rajak (anon. to classmates)
text:
As It was said in the lecture sides while expanding  the child node we are following this rule 
1)  If Child is not present in Open and closed set : then add it to open sen
2)  If Child is present in Open set  and its cost is less now :  delete old node and add the child with new cost
3)  If Child is present in Closed set :  then update its  cost ( say node is B and its old parent is A and new parent is C after update due to condition 3 )
  Now my question is in case of  UCF : why do we need the third condition . The solution is always  optimal here using  condition  1 and 2 . Because condition 3 is actually saying you have added a node in closed set whose past  cost is   higher. So here node B will never get added in closed set before  node as path cost from startnode--A is aways higher then pathcost from startnode---C
if                    startnode------A-B > startnode--------C-B 
that means    condition 1  (  startnode------A  >  startnode--------C  and (A-B is smaller then C-B) 
                      condition 2   (  startnode------A  <  startnode--------C  and (A-B is greater then C-B)  
In any case  it will always remove C before A and their is no way B will be added to the closed set . So we dont need condition 3 for UCS
  Question : For A* I agree depending  upon wether you considered  condition 3 or nor  our answer will vary. And I am guessing we are allowed here both version (with and without condition 3 ) for HW1

title: Definition of Global Constraint (Constraint Satisfaction Problem)
author: Chai Zheng Xin
text:
Hi, in the textbook, a global constraint is defined as one involving an arbitrary number of variables (but not necessarily all variables).
I am confused by this definition.
  When a constraint is defined, the number of involved variables would be fixed. And you will call the constraint by the appropriate name (i.e. 2 -> binary and 3 -> ternary). So when would a constraint be called global?

author: David Abrego-Bellis
student_answer.text:
As I understand it, a global constraint is the conjunction (AND-ing) of all members of the set of constraints that are applied to the CSP.
For example, if the the variables X = {x1, x2, x3} have the set of binary constraints C = {(x1 != x2), (x1 != x3), (x2 != x3)}, then the conjunction of all these constraints can be described by the global constraint G = alldifferent(x1, x2, x3).

followup.name: Chai Zheng Xin
followup.text: On further thought, I think the book refers to global constraints when talking about techniques that apply generally to constraints that can have any number of variables. Therefore, global constraint might just be a super set (i.e. binary constraint is a global constraint so are unary and ternary constraints.

replies.name: Chai Zheng Xin
replies.text: Global definition is first mentioned in page 211 of the textbook.

replies.name: Thomas Collins
replies.text: Global constraint is just a term used to generally denote constraints among some number of variables. Binary and ternary constraints refer to constraints involving two or three variables respectively, while global constraints are those that involve any number of variables (1, 2, 4, all of them, etc). So, in some sense, they are a general term that refers to all such constraints. However, the term generally is used for higher-order constraints involving many variables (or all the variables).

title: Clean Robust Algorithm
author: Archit Srivastava
text:
Let's say there is a loop from node A to node A in a graph.
  The algorithm given in the slides indicates that you should
  1. Pop the node from the open queue.
2. Explore children.
    2.1 If the child is in neither(open and closed) queue enqueue the child in the open queue
    .... Other conditions...
3. Put the node in the closed set.
  Considering this, let's say we reach node A from B. A is now in the open queue.
It is popped out of it. Its children are explored (consisting of A).
The child A is evaluated against the condition 2.1. Since A is in neither queue, it is enqueued again and A is marked its parent.
  The node A is now put in the closed set.
  Now A has a self-parent loop while doing the search and loop detection essentially fails for an interim period.

Have I gone wrong somewhere? 
    EDIT:
eg.

UCS
B
C
3
B A 1
A A 0
A C 1
0

Results:
1. B is put in open queue.
2. B is popped out of open queue. A is inserted into open queue and B is marked as parent of A. B is put into the closed set.
3. A is popped out of open queue. Its children A and C are inserted into open queue with costs 1 and 2 respectively and their parents marked as A. A is put into the closed set.
4. A is popped out of the open queue but since it's already in the closed set and its cost is not less than previous, it is ignored. It's put into the closed set.
5. C is popped out of the open queue. Since it is goal, it is returned.
  Now, C's parent is A, but A's parent is again A -> Loop.

followup.name: Archit Srivastava
followup.text: I've updated the question with an input. Please check.

replies.name: Muye Zhu (anon. to classmates)
replies.text: when A is reached again as in A A 0, this new optional route does not improve the current known shortest distance to B which is 1. Therefore A shouldn't be enqueued again.

replies.name: Archit Srivastava
replies.text:
The exact pseudo-code described in the slides is as follows:
  currnode  Remove-Front(open)
.
.
.
if no node in open or closed has child’s state ..... (1)
open  Queuing-Fn(open, child)
.
.
.
  When A is popped out of the open queue, it is not in the open or the closed set. It's child "A" will be evaluated against condition (1).
As that is true, A is enqueued again in the open queue and A is made its parent.
The child A node doesn't go to the 2nd or the 3rd conditions for evaluation.

replies.name: Muye Zhu (anon. to classmates)
replies.text: for A->A with non zero cost the node A will eventually have higher cost than other nodes in heap. In your example with A A 0, in condition (1) a simple test to exclude child that has same state as parent is sufficient, since for all intents and purposes to do self loop does not help to solve the problem.

replies.name: Archit Srivastava
replies.text: I concede that there should be an additional check in place and the loop will no longer be there or the algorithm should be modified. The pseudo-code in itself, without modifications, will lead to self-loops, that is my only concern.

replies.name: Daniel Link
replies.text:
There's not going to be "A A 0". Remember, this is supposed to be live traffic data. This implies that you get data about connections between two intersections that are not the same.
  Additionally, really why don't you just run the "clean, robust" UCS algorithm and check for yourself with a possible loop (e.g. one between three intersections)?

title: Turing test
author: Suxin Li
text: Why is the statement of "The Turing test defines the conditions under which a machine can be said to be ‘intelligent‘” false? And what is the correct statement?

followup.name: Luenin
followup.text:
hi Suxin,
  The statement is false.  The standard Turing test does not include tests for other important factors involved in intelligence, such as the sense of smell or the sense of touch.  A more accurate test would be the extended Turing test which does test for those factors and better defines the conditions under which machines can be considered intelligent.

replies.name: Jaeho Lee
replies.text: I'm a little confused on this statement. In the discussion note, it shows that computer AI passes Turing test which have intelligence. If the statement is false, we can't say that AI pass Turing test.

replies.name: Wei Huang (anon. to classmates)

followup.name: David Abrego-Bellis
followup.text: In the notes for the first lecture it says "Alan Turing's 1950 article discussed conditions for considering a machine to be intelligent". In the exam review notes from the fifth discussion it says the following statement is FALSE: "the Turing test defines the conditions under which a machine can be said to be intelligent". So does the distinction hinge on the word 'discussed' versus the word 'defines'? The first lecture notes go on to say that "the Turing test is not amenable to mathematical analysis" which would also indicate that the Turing test has not defined anything. If we focus on Turing's phrase 'imitation game', then perhaps the most we can say about a machine that successfully imitates a human is that it might be intelligent.

replies.name: Mingxuan Yue
replies.text: Turing was attempting to discover some conditions which can to some degree measure the intelligence of an AI, he didn't define any thing and those conditions cannot make sure those AI passed all conditions are intelligent.

title: α - β pruning
author: Jichao Zhong
text:
There are two versions pseudo-code for α - β pruning. The first one is from the slides, and the second one is from the textbook(P170)
The second one use a temporary variable v to store the value of that node, however the first one does not.
How does the first one work without storing the value of node?
It will always return the value of α not the value of that node.
As for α = MAX(α1, MIN-VALUE(s, game, α2, β)) in the first one, I think α1 and α2 are different, so we should distinguish them with a node value like the second one.

author: Chai Zheng Xin
Vibhu Tiwari
student_answer.text:
The first one uses the global variables α and β to store the local values of the nodes. Its just that because α and β store the corresponding best option found so far for max and min respectively, thus it will not matter if we are not using a local variable to store the value of each node locally. Because at the end if I start my move from max I will look at the the best possible move I can attain i.e. α and same can be said for min i.e. β

However, there might be a typo in lecture slide's version. In MAX-VALUE's "if alpha >= beta, return beta", the return value should be alpha. In MIN-VALUE's "if beta <= alpha, return alpha", the return value should be beta.

followup.name: Jichao Zhong
followup.text:
if we do not have a local variable to store the node value, how can 2 at the bottom be returned so that we can do the pruning.
If what we have is just the global α, the returned value is also α which is 6.
α = max(α, min-value(...)) = max(6, 2) = 6, which will be returned.
Though the value of α is maintained, but 2 gets lost.

replies.name: Thomas Collins
replies.text: I would use the tool I posted in the instructors response to run a tree with this situation and see how the alpha and beta values change. Also, as the recursion unwinds, the backed up values are computed and stored. See, e.g., the update to v in the min-value function (within the loop over actions)

replies.name: Jichao Zhong
replies.text:
I understand how this algorithm works with the second version.
But when I run the first one step by step, I got stuck because of losing 2.
There is a similar situation within the link above.
If we follow the first code, beta (=3) will be return rather than the actual value (15).

replies.name: Thomas Collins
replies.text: The value of 2 is not lost. If I understand what you are asking and your example, I believe you are confusing min and max at the specified node. When min explores the left subtree and finds a value of 2 by exploring down to a terminal state, it would take the minimum over the values, not the maximum. Where is this example from, by the way, so that I can take a closer look. The one at that top of this follow up discussion, I mean.

replies.name: Jichao Zhong
replies.text: Thanks for reply!

replies.name: Thomas Collins
replies.text:
Hello, 

I think I see what you are saying now. You are asking about the version of alpha/beta in the slides, correct? You are saying you understand the version in the book but not the slides, right? I would focus on the version in the book. I personally have not seen the version in the slides before. It may be from a previous version of the textbook. title: Alpha-beta
author: Wei Huang (anon. to classmates)
text: In the node F, why we did not change the value of Alpha into 6, but in the node G, we did.

author: Jichao Zhong
student_answer.text:
At F, a=-inf, b=4; v=6 > b, so we can do the pruning at F. Since MIN node can have value 4, whatever is larger than 4 will be ignored. 
When v >= b, v will be returned, and the function ends, so a won't be updated.
The initial value at F is -inf,
at N, v = MAX(v, MIN-VALUE(...)) = MAX(-inf, 6) = 6
and v > b (=4), the loop ends, we won't look at O, and a won't be updated.
  At G, a=4, b=+inf; v=9 > 4 & < +inf, so we update a to 9.
The initial value at G is -inf,
at P, v = MAX(v, MIN-VALUE(...)) = MAX(-inf, 9) = 9
at Q, v = MAX(v, MIN-VALUE(...)) = MAX(9, 5) = 9
and v < b (=+inf), a = MAX(a, v) = MAX(4, 9) = 9

Example from discussion about Iterative Deepening Search: 
Why the solution:
States popped off OPEN:
S , S , B , C , S , B , E , F , C , G1

author: Shashank Shekhar

S , S , B , C , S , B , E , F , C , G1

followup.name: Harpreet Kaur Randhawa (anon. to classmates)

replies.name: Khanh Duy Le (anon. to classmates)
replies.text:
Because IDS combines the best of breadth-first and depth-first search strategies.
You can find it on the IDS algorithm: 
Function Iterative-deepening-Search(problem) returns a solution,
or failure
   for depth = 0 to ∞ do
     result <- Depth-Limited-Search(problem, depth)
   if result succeeds then return result
end
return failure

title: Query on slides for Week 2, Aug 29th class
author: Disha Punjabi (anon. to classmates)
text:
Screen_Shot_20160929_at_2.58.13_PM.png
  Can anyone help me with understanding how the state space for 8-puzzle became 362,880?

followup.name: Disha Punjabi (anon. to classmates)
followup.text:
Great! Thanks a lot, I understand now.
For confirming that I understood properly, I wanted to discuss the successor states in local search for an 8-queen problem. 
Can we say that- One queen in a column can be moved to 7 other places in the same column and
we can do this for all the eight queens, resulting in 7*8 = 56 possible successor states?

replies.name: Thomas Collins
replies.text:
It depends on the transition model used in the problem. If you are considering a transition model where you can pick one of the 8 questions and move it to any one of 7 other places in its current column, then yes, I agree that there should be 56 successor states. Think about it in terms of selection: 
  You can select one of the 8 queens (8 possibilities). Then you can select any of the 7 open spaces in that column to move (if we ignore constraints). In theory actually, I suppose you could move the queen to the same spot in its column, resulting in 8*8 = 64 successor states. Again, it depends on the transition model you specify and whether or not you are considering the constraints when moving the queens. But 56 (if you don't consider moves that don't actually cause the queen to change tiles) or 64 (if you do consider moves that keep the queen in its current place) will give you an upper bound.

title: Stochastic Vs Nondeterministic
author: Jason Tan
text:
Hi,
  I'm confused about the difference between Stochastic Vs Nondeterministic.  The book says stochastic implies uncertainty about outcomes is quantified in terms of probabilities.  Nondeterministic is one which actions are characterized by their possible outcomes, but no probabilities are attached to them.  
  Can you give an example of both to show the difference?
  Thanks,
Jason

author: Hannes Leipold (anon. to classmates)
student_answer.text:
Stochastic processes are processes that have to do with probabilities and uncertainty, as you said. A good example is a random walk, because at every point in time, you have a certain chance of going one way or the other. We also include randomness in our simulated annealing, where we make "bad" local moves with an exponentially small probability.
  Nondeterministic processes are those usually used in Computation Theory when discussing Turing Machines. Essentially, nondeterministic Turing machines can do several transitions in one step. A deterministic Turing machine can do only one transition in one step. It matters in terms of NP versus P problems, because it seems some problems can be efficiently solved by a nondeterministic Turing machine and not by a deterministic Turing machines. You can always unwind the nondeterminism (by creating a decision tree and taking every step on the tree), but it will lead (in general) to an exponential time deterministic Turing machine algorithm. Sometimes people say NP problems are those that can be verified in polynomial time, because with a particular path down the tree, it is easy to verify that the answer works.

title: Definition of Completeness for Local Search
author: Chai Zheng Xin
text: What does it mean when a local search is complete? When a local search finds a local maximum, is it counted as complete or only when it finds a global maximum? If it is the latter, then what does optimality mean for local search since there is no concept of path?

followup.name: Chai Zheng Xin
followup.text: Then what does optimality mean for local search?

replies.name: Thomas Collins
replies.text: Optimality is something that only has meaning in the context of the function being optimized. The function may have a number of optimal states (e.g., a discrete or continuous problems with multiple global optima/goal states) or a single optimal value (convex function). Optimality is not defined differently for local search than it is any other kind of optimization problem.

The answer given is T.

title: beam search can find the same goal by dfs？
author: Jiangchen Zheng
text:
If depth-first search finds some goal node in finite time, then beam
search will also find a goal node in finite time.
The solution says this is correct. Why can beam search find the goal? Beam search may stuck on local maxmial and can not ensure get global maximal. Why this is right?

followup.name: Jiayi Yao
followup.text:
However, I found in the Wikipedia that "The beam width bounds the memory required to perform the search. Since a goal state could potentially be pruned, beam search sacrifices completeness".
So, even if the DFS can find a goal, beam search may miss the goal. In this situation, can we think that the beam search cannot find a goal in finite time?

replies.name: Thomas Collins
replies.text: I see your point. I assumed that the question utilized random restarts in the local beam search, in which case the statement should be true. If there are no random restarts, then I think you could argue that the statement may not be true. It would probably depend on which version of beam search was being used (there are a number of variations with different properties). Can you point me to where in the slides beam search was discussed? Perhaps the beam search algorithm in the slides has some additional tests/functionality not present in the version presented in the textbook.

title: Is A* always optimal when h(n) is admissible?
author: Jiayuan Huang (anon. to classmates)
text:
I came up this question because the answer of  Fall 2016 Practice Exam Q1.11 is True( but I think it is False). I think if we use a CLOSED set(which means we run graph search), the A* is optimal only if h(n) is consistent. In other words, admissible of h(n) is not enough for A*'s optimal in graph search. Anyone correct me?
  Below refer from wiki:

followup.name: Jiayuan Huang (anon. to classmates)
followup.text: Thank you TC. But what if we encounter this kind of question in exam?Can we assume that admissible actually means admissible and consistent? Like the statement "A* is optimal when heuristic is admissible.". Should we consider it is True?

replies.name: Thomas Collins
replies.text: I wouldn't necessarily say that, as a rule, you should equate the two. When it comes to the exam, it is always best to answer according to what is written. You can also request a regrade. If there is ambiguity in the question, it will be factored in to a regrade request. For this particular question, it could be that it is missing some instructions (perhaps that would have been given verbally) that indicate that you are to assume the search is operating on a tree.  So, you must also factor in what Prof. Itti (or whomever is proctoring) says about assumptions/guidelines for answering questions tomorrow. So, in short, go with what's written and make your case if need be during regrades.

replies.name: Jiayuan Huang (anon. to classmates)
replies.text: OK, Thanks!

title: Practice paper, Local Search, Q6, part (c)
author: Disha Punjabi (anon. to classmates)
text:
Hi,
I came across the solution for the sample exam. I had a query in Q6, part c.
It asks to calculate the total possible states. According to what I understood, column wise, we have 4! , 6!, 3! and so on possibilities in each column. So, overall, we must have 4!*6!*3!... and so on. 
  (Also, I came up with part b solution understanding in the same manner, i.e. each column has 9! possible permutations of numbers, which makes it 9!*9!*9!....  = 9!^9)
  So, I don't think that the answer that is mentioned- 4! + 3! + 6!  (i.e. sum of all columns) is correct.
  Can you please help me understand the same?

title: Question 6c of F16-PracticeQexam1.docx
author: Chai Zheng Xin
text: Why is the total space = 3! + 2 * 4! + 4 * 6 ! + 2 * 8!? Shouldn't it be 3! * (4!)^2 * (6!)^4 * (8!)^2?

author: Qingfeng Du
student_answer.text: As far as I'm concerned. It should be multiplication instead of addition. The sample answer is probably wrong.

followup.name: Sneha Salvi (anon. to classmates)
followup.text: Can some please explain this

replies.name: Hannes Leipold (anon. to classmates)
replies.text:
For each 3x3 block, look at how many are not black. That number factorial is how many choices we have, because we are allowed to exchange any of those states with one another. That is, if we have 5 numbers that are gray, we have 5 slots to place the first number, 4 to place the second number, 3 to place the third number, ... 1 to place the fifth number. This gives you 5!.
  Since this is the case for every block, we have the following math:
  (# of gray numbers in block 1)! * (# of gray numbers in block 2)! * ... * (# of gray numbers in block 9)!
  Filling in for how many gray numbers there are for each block returns the math done by OP.

title: Question on F16-PracticeQExam1 question 1 part 13
author: Chai Zheng Xin
text: Why is this true? If the state space has infinite branching factor and the goal node is on the most bottom-left leave, DFS would find it in finite time but BFS would take infinity.

followup.name: Bi Wang (anon. to classmates)
followup.text:
if the implicit assumption is that the state space and branching factor are finite
part 12 in this question should be true, I think.
  How do you explain it?

replies.name: Thomas Collins
replies.text: DFS can become trapped in infinite loops, even if the state space and branching factor are finite. Also, I said that the assumption is usually finite state spaces and branching factors. That may not always be the case. You have to go with what is written. If you have doubts during the exam, ask one of the teaching staff members to clarify, if you can.

replies.name: Zod (anon. to classmates)
replies.text: Can you give an example where "DFS can become trapped in infinite loops, even if the state space and branching factor are finite"? I think if state space is finite, DFS will sure find a goal, though it may not be optimal.

replies.name: Pedro Arroyo (anon. to classmates)
replies.text: Tree search.

replies.name: Zod (anon. to classmates)
replies.text: I don't think a tree search with finite state space will get DFS stuck, unless there is no goal node at all.

replies.name: Thomas Collins
replies.text: If you do not check for repeated states, the Romania map in the textbook is one example where a loop would be followed endlessly

title: Stake or Raid?
author: Bowen Zhang (anon. to classmates)
text: In homework2, if we occupy a square next to our occupied spaces, but there is no opponent's space can be conquered, what kind of move should we print it out? should it be stake or raid?

followup.name: Sai Shiva Sneha Moyilla (anon. to classmates)
followup.text: Isn't this the scenario where "Raid can be done even if it will not conquer another piece" becomes valid? If we check possible stake actions before checking possible raid actions, then "another valid move might have been for [D,4] to have raided [E,4]" (given in HW-2, figure 2 description) should be stake right (As [E,4] is unoccupied, I will place a new piece on it)?

replies.name: Thomas Collins
replies.text: Yes, a raid can be done in place of a stake in this scenario. I am saying that to ensure that you choose the same moves as the solution, break ties by preferring stake actions over raids in the case where both lead to states of the game board with the same value.

title: Usage of Minimax in actual gameplay
author: Chai Zheng Xin
text: If I am a player in an arbitrary game, is minimax algorithm called each time it is my turn? Isn't it sufficient to simply run minimax at my first turn, recording the moves I made at each max node? Then I simply just replay those moves when it is my turn.

followup.name: Chai Zheng Xin
followup.text: Then would it be possible to say only run minimax on turns beyond your tree depth (say your cutoff depth is 3 so you run minimax only on turns that are multiples of 3)?

replies.name: Luenin
replies.text: You could do that I suppose, but the cost would be astronomically high. It would require generating an additional large number of board states since the tree size explodes the deeper you go.   That is why chess engines limit search, because its a balance between heuristic evaluation function accuracy and space/time efficiency.

followup.name: Luenin
followup.text:
hi Chai,
  As follow up I remembered that checkers,a game with ~5*10^20 states, has been solved.  It has taken them several decades to "solve"  the game, perhaps they attempted some of your ideas. If you're curious you can read about it here:
  http://science.sciencemag.org/content/317/5844/1518

replies.name: Chai Zheng Xin
replies.text: Thanks.

replies.name: Chai Zheng Xin
replies.text: Just to clarify when you say solve, you mean the checkers program knows what to move at each turn without needing to know the opponent's move?

replies.name: Luenin
replies.text: Solved means that the engine plays perfectly and finds the perfect move at each turn. Because of this it correctly predicts the outcome of the game from any board position.

title: Clarification for stake and raid
author: Akshay Deshmukh (anon. to classmates)
text:
Please tell me whether my interpretation is correct for the given moves (Assume that Player 1 is the one to make his/her move):
  1. Stake - A move on an unoccupied tile which is adjacently surrounded by tiles which do not belong to Player 1. So the surrounding adjacent tiles can either belong to Player 2 or be unoccupied.
  2. Raid - A move on an unoccupied tile which is adjacently surrounded by at least one tile which belongs to Player 1.

followup.name: Sami Ullah Kashif
followup.text:
Just to clarify the above with an example.
  Let us say that Player 1 has a symbol on tile (row = 3,col = 3). Assuming that (row = 2, col = 3) is free and (row = 1, col = 3) has Player 2 piece on it, we can do both a Stake and a Raid on (row = 2, col = 3)?
  Simply put, stake can be done on any empty tile?

replies.name: Akshay Deshmukh (anon. to classmates)
replies.text: Stake can be done on an empty tile. A stake on (2,3) will occupy (2,3) only. A raid on (2,3) will occupy (2,3) and (1,3). Can the TAs confirm my answer?

replies.name: Thomas Collins
replies.text: Correct. Stake can be done on any empty tile, but will not raid adjacent pieces controlled by the other player. A raid will take over (1,3) as well as occupying (2,3), while a stake will only occupy (1,3).

title: Tie Breaking
author: Rebecca Johnson
text: I read that if it's between two equal value plays for Stake and Raid you should pick Stake fist by searching those moves first. What about within Stake though, is it not possible that two plays will wind up with the same value? Are we supposed to keep to the order the nodes are listed in the file again for ordering? Alpha/Numerical ordering?

followup.name: Han Zhao
followup.text:
For 
1 2
3 4
  Do you mean "1234" of "1324" by "top left to bottom right"? Thank you.

followup.name: James Webb
followup.text: Say we had the option to do Stake 1, 2, 3, and 4 as Han described and they all had the same value. Do we use the first such value we encounter (position 1) or the last (position 4)? From the book pseudocode it simply says "argmin" or "return the action that has value v".

replies.name: Thomas Collins
replies.text: When minimizing or maximizing look for strict inequality before updating the value. So, in the case you mentioned, if all 4 had the same value, the program would choose the first option (Stake 1). During maximization, it would start with some initially tiny value (-infinity), look at the first action (Stake 1), see that it had some bigger value (say 5). Then it would look through the remaining actions, see that they all had a value of 5, and not update the optimal action or action value further.

title: What should be output expected ?
author: Yinghui Hao
text:
On what basis should be prioritized? What should be expected output out of following?
B1 Stake
XO
..

A2 Stake
X.
O.

B2 Stake
X.
.O
Smallest column and/or smallest row can be one of possible priority we can give !
#pin

followup.name: Thomas Collins
followup.text:
There are two orderings being discussed: 

1. The order in which you search tiles on the board. This should be done from top left to bottom right. In other words, if you view the game board as an n x n matrix, iterate over the tiles in a natural order: (0, 0), (0,1)... to (n-1, n-1). Note that I am using 0-based indices in this example. The homework uses row indices starting at 1 and column indices with letters. But the idea is the same: iterate over the game board in a typical top left to bottom right order. 

2. The order in which neighbors are searched during the search for valid raid actions. 

Search through all stake actions first. When you go to search for raid actions, search through each tile again and determine whether or not you can perform a raid at that tile by searching through the neighbors of that tile. If you do the search this way, you wouldn't need the left, right,  down, up ordering of neighbor, per se, but it wouldn't hurt to have it. 

I believe that you are correct about the second order producing inconsistencies. My apologies. If you search for raid actions as I specified above in 2., that should be consistent with the other ordering and we will ensure that this matches our test cases. Sorry for any confusion caused. 

I will update the answer above to reflect this discussion.

replies.name: Pratik Shrikant Kabara
replies.text:
So what I understood is
1.check all stake action (top left to bottom right)
2.check all raid action (top left to bottom right)
        for each raid action found:
  neighbour checking (left,right,bottom,up)
Please verify. Sorry for extra work you have!

replies.name: Thomas Collins
replies.text: Correct. But note that, if you simply check whether or not there is a valid raid action at each state in order of board tiles (top left to bottom right), it shouldn't matter what order you search the neighbors. If there is at least one neighbor controlled by the player making the move, the raid is valid at that tile (if it is unoccupied). But, searching in the order I gave for neighbors can't hurt.

replies.name: shashi kiran yellappa (anon. to classmates)
replies.text:
Hi Thomas,
  According to your last statement or conclusion the ordering of possible raid tiles will be [up,left,right,bottom] as we are checking empty tiles from left top to bottom right. but previously you had mentioned as [left,right,bottom,top] checking for valid raid tiles. So could you please confirm which one to follow?

replies.name: Thomas Collins
replies.text:
Sorry, there was a little confusion here, and I removed that part of the specification in my answer above, as it may cause incorrect ordering. The right thing to do is as follows:
  1. Search through all stake actions from top left to bottom right
2. Search through all raid actions from top left to bottom right
  To determine whether or not a raid can be performed at tile (X,Y), look at its neighbors and see if the player also owns one of the neighboring pieces. If the player does own at least one such piece and (X,Y) is open, then a raid can be performed. Do this for all (X,Y) from top left to bottom right to find the raid actions. If you search the actions in order as above and only update them when an action of strictly better value is found, you will arrive at the correct answer in cases of tie-breaking. The reason the order of the neighbors doesn't matter is you are only using them to determine whether or not a raid is performable at a given tile (X,Y). then you will get a list of raid actions in order of the board (top left to bottom right), and the order in which you test neighbors does not matter. We wanted to simplify the tie-breaking rules, which is why we changed from the original neighbor-ordering part. Sorry if that caused any confusion.

replies.name: shashi kiran yellappa (anon. to classmates)
replies.text: Thanks for the clarification :)

followup.name: Yuqian chen (anon. to classmates)
followup.text:
So for a tile with possible conquering neighbors, we can first consider choosing not to conquer its neighbors and call it stake and calculate the value of it? Then consider conquering its neighbors and call it raid and calculate the value of it?
  Does the rule allow us to not conquer any neighbors when we can?

replies.name: Sriram
replies.text:
Yes. and since all the values of the tiles are positive, the eval will be higher when you raid and conquer an opponent's position rather than stake at that position.
  The tie breaker rules apply when the eval function gives you the same value for two moves.

title: neither "not passed" nor "passed"
author: Ulan Korabay (anon. to classmates)
text:
In my grade report I have 12 test cases which do not have neither "not passed" nor "passed".
When I tried to run them on my PC I got "RecursionError: maximum recursion depth exceeded while getting the repr of a tuple" error.
As long as homework 1 assignment did not have any boundaries on size of the input, I think my algorithm did not fail in those test cases. It is just limitations that I could not predict. Therefore, I am asking to count these test cases  as "passed".
Please let me know your decision on this problem.

followup.name: Ulan Korabay (anon. to classmates)
followup.text: Yes. That is correct. There are no output because python does not allow deeper recursions and algorithm fail. But it fails not because logic is broken.(Algorithm works fine on smaller input). I could not know in advance that deep recursion will be problem. The assignment did not specify how big  the input data will be. Therefore I could not assume in advance if there are 20 nodes in input or 20 000. If assignment would specify that input will be big I would check if bigger data is working.

replies.name: Daniel Link
replies.text:
I'd be interested in two things:
  Which of our test cases, in your opinion, were unreasonably complex, and why?
What recursion depth are you actually reaching when you're getting the recursion error?
  Recursion always carries with it the potential for stack overflow, but the stack is usually big enough for this to indicate an implementation issue. My guess would be that either you're passing huge objects as parameters on the stack or you're going thousands of levels deep. Realistically, I'm not seeing how any of our test cases could go deeper than the amount of nodes, which is generally not very big if you look at all the test cases.
  We cannot make bold assumptions about students' computers in our assignments, so we're generally designing our test cases so they can be run reasonably fast and without hitting resource constraints (e.g. disk space, memory) on machines that are not so fancy.
  Based on this, it looks like the default recursion depth that Python allows is 1000. If you're reaching a thousand levels of recursion with our test cases, it's a strong indication that your implementation is wrong.
  If you have any data to counter this, I'd be very interested.

replies.name: Mingxuan Yue
replies.text: I also implemented a solution using Python and run all test cases, there's no such error. We don't have test cases require that many recursions. The most possibility is that you implementation is wrong and ends in a dead loop.

followup.name: Ulan Korabay (anon. to classmates)

text:
Hi,

XO.
X..
O..
If this the state of board right now and its O's turn to play and if my code says C1 is the optimal move, should the move be Raid(Without Conquer) or Stake?
Also what's the difference between Raid w/o Conquer and Stake? Both of them are going to give the same resultant state if I'm not wrong.

followup.name: Avinash Venugopal (anon. to classmates)
followup.text:
Hi ,
Thanks for the answer. So in this case , should it be Raid without Conquer or Stake? As B1 has O and C1 is adjacent to it, should be considered a Raid or Stake?

replies.name: Avinash Venugopal (anon. to classmates)
replies.text: Sorry, I got the answer. Thanks!

followup.name: Avinash Venugopal (anon. to classmates)
followup.text: So, according to the method mentioned, we first explore all stake options and then the raid options. Since Stake and Raid without Conquer gives us the same answer, when it comes down to Stake and Raid w/o Conquer, we always choose Stake right?

replies.name: Thomas Collins
replies.text: Correct

followup.name: Jake Zidow (anon. to classmates)
followup.text: If you lay a tile next to an adjacent tile we control, and will capture an enemy territory if this move is labeled a Raid, can we still call label this move a stake and therefore not conquer the adjacent enemy territory while expanding our previous territory?

replies.name: Jake Zidow (anon. to classmates)
replies.text: To elaborate the above question, in the example in this original post, if there had been an X in C2 and it was O's turn to move, could we Stake C1 therefore not capturing the X in C2 even though we had the opportunity to Raid? (Assuming the GameScore equaled out at the depth we were going too regardless of Stake C1 or Raid C1)

replies.name: Thomas Collins
replies.text: It is a legal move to stake any unoccupied tile, whether or not you control a neighboring one. In other words, there may be tiles in which a stake or a raid is possible. You must consider all legal moves at each board state. That being said, I am having a hard time coming up with a situation where minimax would select such an action over a raid, but I suppose it may not be possible. At any rate, it is a legal move and should be considered.

replies.name: Luenin
replies.text: I think it is always advantageous to raid and capture squares compared to performing a stake.  The game is about cell value ownership, so increasing your territory is to your benefit.  Imagine a depth of 1 where your program decided to stake instead of raid.   That may not be the best choice.

followup.name: Anuja Shantaram Dawane (anon. to classmates)
followup.text: So what do we call this output? C1 Raid or C1 Stake?

replies.name: Thomas Collins
replies.text: In general, you will just pick the action with the best minimax value. By ordering all stake actions before raid actions and ordering the raid actions in order of location on the board (top left to bottom right), you will find that your program selects the correct action. If C1 Stake and C1 Raid both led to the same utility value, then your program will prefer C1 Stake (as it is encountered first and C1 Raid is not strictly better). So, with the proper ordering and only updating when a move that is strictly better is found, you will get the correct answer.

title: tie breaking
author: Anuja Shantaram Dawane (anon. to classmates)
text:
Can someone elaborate on when there is a tie breaking we need to pick the stake and not raid.
I am not understanding this clearly, can someone give an example and clear it please?
Thanks.

author: Han Zhao
student_answer.text:
1 1 1
1 1 1
1 1 3
X.O
...
...
  You are 'X'.
DEPTH = 1

followup.name: Anuja Shantaram Dawane (anon. to classmates)
followup.text:
the output should be C3 Stake and not B1 Raid...
Correct??

replies.name: Thomas Collins
replies.text:
Correct for the above example. But this is not a tie-breaking scenario. A tie-breaking scenario would be when all moves lead to utility value 1. So, in the following example: 
  1 1 1 
1 1 1
1 1 1
  X.. 
...
.. O
  X could perform a raid or stake at B1. At depth 1, they both lead to a utility value of 1. Since, however, you are searching through stakes before raids, you will find B1 Stake at a utility value of 1 first. When you get to processing B1 Raid, you will find that it also leads to a value of 1. You will not update the optimal action though, as it is not strictly better. This is an example of tie-breaking. Post @292 gives the tie-breaking rules. As long as you follow those, you should get the correct answer

replies.name: Anuja Shantaram Dawane (anon. to classmates)
replies.text: Thank you!

replies.name: Han Zhao
replies.text:
Dear instructor Collins,

It should be a tie-breaking scenario. C3 Stake and B1 Raid will both get 3 points.
However, you seems to have different ways to break ties in different posts.
  In @322, it is said that "look through each tile in order, and determine whether or not a raid can be performed at that tile." Then the answer should be B1 Raid.
  In @292, it is said that "all stake actions before raid actions". Then the answer should be C3 Stake.

replies.name: Thomas Collins
replies.text:
Sorry, I think I misread your post initially. Yes it is a tie-break situation, and the answer should be C3 Stake. 

In @322, the poster was specifically asking about raid actions and avoiding searching the same raid action multiple times. I was only talking about raid actions when I said what you quoted, and I was just offering guidance on how to determine the possible raid actions for a given board state. The tie breaking rules of @292 still stand: 
  1. Search through stake actions first.
2. Then search through raid actions
3. Update the optimal action only when one of strictly better value is found.

replies.name: Han Zhao
replies.text: Thank you!

replies.name: Thomas Collins
replies.text: No problem. Sorry for misreading your post initially.

title: Raid and stake confusion
author: Om Patri
text:
If I make a move that extends one of my pieces and the newly placed piece touches at least one of the opponent's pieces. Is it mandatory to conquer the opponent's pieces in this case or it depends on our evaluation function or overall algorithmic consideration?
  i.e. lets say we start from here:
OO.
..X
.XX
and it is O's turn to play.
O decides to iterate over it's Stake branches from top left to bottom right, it places its piece in C1 as below:
Let's call this (1)
OOO     
O.X
.XX
I would think that the above is not a valid Stake since it is mandatory to conquer the opponent's state which is at C2 and the board looks like this:
Let's call this (2)
OOO     
O.O
.XX
  Is my understanding correct, that (1) is not a valid Stake and there cannot be a Raid without a conquer, if it touches the opponent's piece.

followup.name: Sai Shiva Sneha Moyilla (anon. to classmates)
followup.text: Given a board state where raid with conquer is possible, the player would always chose it, as it increases his score. The player wouldn't consider performing either stake or raid without conquer. Can you please let me know why do we have to consider stake and raid without conquer as valid actions in such a scenario.

replies.name: Thomas Collins
replies.text:
For a couple of reasons: 
  1. In order to ensure proper behavior you must consider all valid actions. Minimax is only optimal against an opponent if it considers all possible alternative actions. The rules of the game allow for such moves, so they must be accounted for.
2. What seems good in the short term (one move look ahead) may not always be optimal long term (say, 5 move look ahead). For instance, what if raiding the opponent pieces set the opponent up to raid you back in a way that causes you to lose many points? The point is, in order to ensure we don't run into such suboptimal solutions by not looking far enough ahead (in terms of moves), we need to consider all possible options.

replies.name: Thomas Collins
replies.text: Also, just to be clear, this is no such action as Raid without conquer or Stake with conquer. There are only Stake and Raid actions. The cells to which they are applied determine the transition to the next board state (e.g., whether or not a tile changes from one player's control to another when a raid is performed).

replies.name: Anushree Kaipa Ramanath (anon. to classmates)
replies.text:
Can you please give an example where, in the longterm choosing a Stake action over Raid would prove to be a better option? 
I do not understand how this result will be better when we are searching the tree for a fixed depth.

replies.name: Xiaokang Sun
replies.text:
I don't think we could get a better value by applying Stake instead of Raid.
The former method may have the same value with the latter one, at most, but not exceed.

replies.name: Anuja Shantaram Dawane (anon. to classmates)
replies.text: No, what i meant by that is , when we traverse till depth 4, i find 2 states with evaluation 26 each. when i return the values back to the root, on depth 1(where we have to choose our next move) one is a result of stake and the other is a result of raid. which one to pick?

replies.name: Thomas Collins
replies.text: I printed out the values for all the actions at that depth in our reference implementation. The value of A4 Stake and A5 Stake should not be anywhere near the value of C3 Raid. So, this is not a case of tie-breaking throwing things off, but, rather, it would seem that the values you are computing are not correct. I think I misunderstood your question initially . Sorry for that.

replies.name: Anuja Shantaram Dawane (anon. to classmates)
replies.text:
Why are we comparing values of c3 stake and a5 raid. We are going to depth 4. So we will compare what value did c3 stake cause at depth 4 and return it. Then again what value did A5 stake cause at depth 4 and return it. 
When given depth is 4 we compare the values at depth 4 right?
When depth would have been 1 I would compare between C3 raid and A5 stake , if they are giving me equal values then I pick the stake. Correct me if I'm wrong.

replies.name: Thomas Collins
replies.text: Correct, you must compare the backed up minimax values of each action. The backed up values are propagated up from the given depth (e.g., 1, 2, 4). If the backed up values are the same (maximal), for example, for exactly one raid action and exactly one stake action (at a certain depth), you should prefer the stake action.

replies.name: Anuja Shantaram Dawane (anon. to classmates)
replies.text:
That's what is happening with this example. 
C3 raid and A5 stake are both having values propagated from depth 4 as 26. For alpha beta. Hence the output changes to A5 stake and not C3 raid.
While for minimax it still remains to be C3stake
I guess the change is happening coz we are pruning nodes. The condition v<=(alpha) of our algorithm.

replies.name: Thomas Collins
replies.text: That is not correct. Alpha Beta does not change the optimal solution. This is an indication that something is not correctly implemented in your Alpha Beta. Both algorithms will return the exact same answer, except that Alpha Beta will usually take quite a bit less time (for larger inputs).

  3
MINIMAX
O
2

26 30 9

  Then at depth 1 - i will look for all possible move of X for each move O made

title: static and episodic
author: Luyao Wang (anon. to classmates)
text: Hello, if an environment is static, then it is episodic. Is it right?

author: Bojun Huang
Sami Ullah Kashif
student_answer.text:
I don't think so. They are both different kind of categorization of environments. 
  Static means that the environment is not changing while the agent is deliberating on it's move
Episodic means that the result of the current move will have no effect on the subsequent moves.
  Chess is static but not episodic.
  An instructor can correct me if I am wrong

followup.name: Luyao Wang (anon. to classmates)
followup.text: I don't know but in the slide, for the wumpus problem. said it is episodic because static?

followup.name: David Abrego-Bellis
followup.text: I would say the Wumpus world is Sequential. For example, if you shoot your one arrow into an empty square because you think the Wumpus might be there, then you have lost your arrow and have not killed the Wumpus. This will prevent you from killing the Wumpus later. The decision to shoot certainly has an effect on subsequent moves.

replies.name: David Abrego-Bellis
replies.text: Slide 9 of Prof. Tejada's F2016Lecture-9.pdf says the Wumpus World is not Episodic - "sequence of action to get reward".

followup.name: Jake Zidow
followup.text:
Sami, Dr. Itti told me in office hours that chess is episodic. I believe it was because the difference in moves is only contingent on changes of internal states.
  David, Dr. Itti explained to me that Wumpus is episodic for the same reason. However your point about the arrow is strong so I'm not sure.

In this case, F6 Stake gives the same result as E0 Raid (since we are only searching to depth 1), and it is a stake action so it should be chosen over the raid action.
