title: Query about the given test, Test 8
author: Ratan George Senapathy
text:
In test case number 8 the input is given as:
4
ALPHABETA
X
6
4 1 2 4
2 3 1 2
4 3 3 4
3 3 3 2
...X
X..X
O..O
...O
  The output that is given in the example is:
A1 Stake
X..X
X..X
O..O
...O
  Shouldn't this be a raid according to the problem definition. The guidelines mentioned that occupying a free space next to a space which is already occupied by you is a raid.

author: Thomas Collins
Shreyas Singapura
student_answer.text: If both stake and raid actions result in the same game score, we should give preference to stake.

followup.name: Ratan George Senapathy
followup.text: I know stakes are given preference to raid, but that shouldn't matter in this case. You are occupying A1. A piece is next to it in A2 which is of the same type. However you look at it it should be a raid. I understand that when you place a piece at two different positions and generate the same score where one is a stake and the other is a raid, then stake should be chosen, but in this case it will always be raid since A1 is a raid cell.

replies.name: Thomas Collins
replies.text: This is not true. The fact that a neighboring cell is owned by  X makes a raid at A1 allowed. The fact that the tile is open means that a stake is a valid action at A1. Both actions lead to the same resulting state and the same utility value, but this won't always be the case. There is no such thing as a raid cell. There is a valid stake action at every cell at which a raid could be performed. But the converse is not true. There are tiles where a stake can be performed but a raid cannot.

replies.name: Mengjiong Qian (anon. to classmates)
replies.text: In the description of "Raid", it says "A Raid can be done even if it will not conquer another piece.", Also in description of Figure 2, "A raid always creates a new piece adjacent to an existing one, but it does not conquer another piece unless it is touching it. Thus, another valid move might have been for [D,4] to have raided [E,4]. Then the green player would own [D,4] and [E,4] but would have conquered none of blue’s pieces.". It seems like occupying A2 is also called 'raid' under these descriptions.

replies.name: Thomas Collins
replies.text: Correct. A raid could be performed at A1 as well. I am saying that a stake is a valid move at A1 as well. They are two separate moves and the program must determine which one to perform. In other words, the program could choose to stake instead of raid a tile, even if that would cause it to miss out on taking over opponent tiles. There is a difference between a good move, and a possible move. Minimax makes this decision based entirely on utility values. But both raid and stake are possible moves and minimax has to consider all possible moves. Raiding is not automatic. The program must deliberately select the move raid over the move stake at a certain square (which it will if it leads to higher utility states).

followup.name: Ulan Korabay
followup.text:
My algorithm gives Raid in ALPHABETA mode, but Stake in MINIMAX mode. Is my algorithm is wrong? or I should/may manually check if I could do Stake instead of Raid, after ALPHABETA is finished?
As long as I cannot check entire tree by hand, I assume that Raid occurred earlier than Stake or Stake was pruned earlier. Therefore, I think Raid is also correct. Please comment on this

replies.name: Shreyas Singapura
replies.text:
Irrespective of the algorithm, the result should be the same. Only the execution time should be better for alpha_beta. 
  You should first check for stake actions, and then raid actions. If raid action has the same game score as stake, stake is chosen.

replies.name: Ulan Korabay
replies.text: Problem solved. Global alpha beta caused the problem

replies.name: Michelle (anon. to classmates)
replies.text: what do you mean by "global alpha beta" caused the problem?

replies.name: Thomas Collins
replies.text: I think what Ulan means is that alpha and beta were being stored as global variables rather than passed down locally through the recursive stack. Look at the pseudocode for alpha-beta pruning in the book and ensure that you understand that Alpha and Beta must be passed down as parameters to ensure that the program functions correctly.

title: Test case 7, same score with different moves
author: Liang Chen
text:
In test case 7, the given output is:
F6 Stake
...X.O
......
......
......
......
.....O, which gives a score of 3 (4-1).
But if I take
E1 Raid,
...OOO
......
......
......
......
......, which gives the same score 3 (3-0).
What kind of search order should I follow? Should I start from up-left to bottom right to take possible moves, or should I search all stake first then raid?
  Thank you!

author: Sriram
student_answer.text:
You have to look at the moves that can be generated from each of the board. Not compare the two test cases.
  In 7th, Stake at F6 provides same utility as Raid at E1. and Stake is preferred over Raid. So we chose Stake over Raid.
...X.O
......
......
......
......
.....O
      in 6th, Raid at E1 is clearly provides us with a better board than Stake at F6.
E1 Raid,
...OOO
......
......
......
......
......
  In 7th, its Utility(F6) =  3 and in 6th, Utility(F6) = 2

followup.name: Mohak Kothari
followup.text: But isn't minimax and alpha beta pruning provide same answer? How come in  stake is better than raid as they provide same utility and raid board is also favorable for the player than stake board?

replies.name: Sriram
replies.text:
They should provide the same answer.
  Also for your follow up "raid board is also favorable for the player than stake board", Can you make it clear?
  Both the test cases have for depth=1. Its easy for you to create all the necessary boards and decide which move is better.
Test case 7
two of the possible moves (other moves are pretty much the same and will have lesser eval than these two),
F6 Stake (eval= 4-1 = 3)
E1 Raid (eval=3-0 = 3)
Since both the moves give you the same utility, you choose a stake.
  Test case 6
two possible moves,
F6 Stake (eval= 3-1 = 2)
E1 Raid (eval=3-0 = 3)
So you choose a raid (gives you a better eval).

replies.name: Sriram
replies.text:
Heap Space Concern:
Heap space errors are caused by storing a lot of redundant information in the memory. If you look at the definition of the game board, a basic design would be to create the entire board every step, you may wanna think whether you want to store all this information every time.
  Infinite loop Issue:both Minimax and Alpha-Beta Pruning are designed to terminate at the right time. Check if your terminal conditions are correctly designed.

For Java, in particular, we will ensure this by running our test implementation on any test cases we generate. title: Makefiles for Competition
author: Chai Zheng Xin
text:
I am not clear about makefiles.
Does it mean I need a minimum of 2 make files (run and agent)? Do I name those files "run.txt" and "agent.txt"?
Furthermore, if my program has no calibration logic, will my agent.txt file only be a single line, "g++ -std=c++11 homework11.cpp -o homework.out" and my run.txt be a single line, "./homework.out"?

author: Chai Zheng Xin
student_answer.text:
I figured it out. You just need to create a single file, "makefile". Within it, you can specify different make targets. For my case, I only need "agent" and "run" targets so my makefile would look like:
  agent:
g++ -std=c++11 homework11.cpp -o homework.out
run:
./homework.out

title: Problem from test case 3 !
author: Hao Liu (anon. to classmates)
text:
According to the pseudo code from textbook, we initialize alpha and beta once with negative infinity and positive infinity at top root of tree.
  But problem shows up in test case 3, which is
  5
ALPHABETA
X
4
20 16 1 32 30
20 12 2 11 8
28 48 9 1 1
20 12 10 6 2
25 30 23 21 10
..XX.
..XOX
...O.
..OO.
.....
  In this case, C3 Raid and A5 Stake will have same return value of 26. However, according to previous post from piazza, Stake has higher priority than Raid. So we should choose A5 Stake instead of C3 Raid in the given output.
  I am wondering if there is something wrong with this output?
Should we reassign alpha and beta to negative infinity and positive infinity when player first consider an applicable cell on board,
or initialize alpha and beta once with negative infinity and positive infinity at top root of tree, in other word, each applicable cell is a child of this root node.
  Really need help of TAs, thank you in advance.

author: Shreyas Singapura
student_answer.text:
Priority:
  1. Stake: top left to bottom right, row major
2. Raid: top left to bottom right, row major and only if strictly lower cost than Stake

followup.name: Guanzhou Liu (anon. to classmates)
followup.text:
The same problem here, I also get the wrong result from test case 3, and I think I need to clarify the problem here:
  First, I have to say it is ok to set stake higher priority than raid in minimax algorithm, because in minimax we get value from fully explored tree. So any equal value we get in minimax is accurate and exact.
  But in alpha-beta pruning, we can't give this priority as we do in minimax. (if we are adhering to the textbook algorithm) In general, our normal alpha-beta pruning algorithm only initialize alpha and beta value once at the root of the tree, which should be -infinity and +infinity. So any later steps will only update alpha and beta value, not initializing them. (here I have to mention this point, because this point is the mainly difference cause the trouble, And I believe lots of students may have this problem if they write their alpha-beta pruning based on their minimax. Because it is easy to write into a different alpha-beta pruning but get same results with test case 3)
  So the different way to do the alpha-beta pruning is that we initialize alpha and beta value every time we get back to depth 1. (in our homework, depth 1 is the step we place our first player on the board)
  Here I will call the normal alpha-beta pruning as #1, and another one as #2.
If we use #1 and #2 both on the same board, we will get different sequence of values at depth 1. Here I will give an example (I think it is also reasonable based on definition):
2
ALPHABETA
X
2
1 2
1 2
..
..
values at depth 1 of #1: -1 0 0 0
values at depth 1 of #2: -1 0 -1 0
  Now lets get back to our homework test case 3
The results of #1:
A5 Stake
..XX.
..XOX
...O.
..OO.
X....
and the values at depth 1 is:
-12 -15 X X -11
-11 -11 X O X
-12 -18 26 O 24
25 25 O O 23
26 26 26 26 23
  The results of #2 is same with test case 3, and the values at depth 1 is:
-12 -16 X X -11
-12 -28 X O X
-12 -46 26 O -31
-35 -28 O O -30
-7 -55 -46 -46 -33
  It is obvious that #2 can give correct answer (I mean "correct" result matched with test case 3), and make me pass every cases provided. But we all know it is wrong, it is not the normal alpha-beta pruning, and it is also not time efficient. 
(Before leaving note here, please check whether you write your alpha-beta correctly)

replies.name: Sriram
replies.text: How do you say #2 implementation is wrong?

replies.name: Guanzhou Liu (anon. to classmates)
replies.text:
I say it is wrong considering the time and space complexity. Because the potential time and space complrxity of #2 is way more higher than #1. And the reason we are using alpha-beta not minimax is to save time and space during execution, right. And #2 is totally not implemented as the pseudo code provided in textbook.
I accept #2 is a different way to implement alpha-beta as I described before. So my problem is why using #2. It does not make sense to use #2 implementation because I only want to match the result with test case 3. So if we insist the priority rule in alpha beta pruning, at least test case 3 should give #1 result.

replies.name: Sriram
replies.text:
I didn't do all the stake and raid prioritizing at any level except the root (because that's where your decision making is required). I did get #2 as output and it doesn't take longer.
  What #2 does is that it changes the order of exploring the possible moves. It takes longer because of the sorting. But this doesn't mean that you get a different output when compared to #1.

replies.name: Guanzhou Liu
replies.text:
I didn't do prioritizing at any level either, I only did it at the root when I get values at depth 1.

I think the problem is the values at depth 1 are different. (Like test case 3 values from #1 and #2, I also tried to run alpha-beta tree on provided 2x2 example by using #1 and #2) That is why the result is different.

replies.name: Aishwarya Verghese (anon. to classmates)
replies.text: I'm getting the same problem here. If I apply an alpha beta pruning at the root I get the output as A5 stake and if I don't I get C3 Raid.

replies.name: Mohak Kothari
replies.text:
Hey guys what should be the solution to it
  whether A5 Stake, A4 Stake or C3 Raid

replies.text: what do you guys mean you didn't do prioritizing until the root level? So this is the only instance you check if steak and raid equal each other?

title: In raid, can I just take partial enemy place when I can take all?
author: Chun-Yuan Chen
text: for example, if I can take 3 enemy place by "Raid", can I only take 2 of them?

author: Chun-Yuan Chen
Sriram
student_answer.text:
No. By definition of the game all neighboring enemy pieces should be automatically conquered by a raid.
  @ChunYuan Chen, not totally with you, TA said raid can take no enemy piece even he could.

followup.name: Wayne Chi
followup.text: So we don't have to raid even when a raid is possible?

replies.name: Garrett Witowski
replies.text: You have to at least try the raid to see if it's a better option. If it's utility value is the same as staking the same position then you're going to end up staking because stakes have priority.

replies.name: Thomas Collins
replies.text: Garret is correct. You have to consider all possible moves.

replies.name: Wayne Chi
replies.text: Ok, so we don't have to raid when a raid is possible. Thanks!

replies.name: Thomas Collins
replies.text: Correct. You can raid or stake, but there is no notion of an intermediate move between the two

title: Do we have to always search all empty blocks as stake moves first in a next-state search?
author: Zod (anon. to classmates)
text:
I'm asking because I find that in several corner cases, a raid and a stake move on a certain empty block has the same score in the end.
  According to @292, we should treat this move as stake. But in the long run, given enough search depth, I think a raid move is sure to prevail. 
  So, given the same predicted score, do we actually have to choose a stake move when raid is valid?

author: Thomas Collins
Garrett Witowski
student_answer.text:
It doesn't matter about the long run. If you can search the whole game tree then of course you'll find the best answer because that's how the algorithm works. Given that we may not be able to search the entire game tree in a reasonable amount of time, we limit the search to a particular depth "d" and that becomes our "entire tree". Sure, it may work out in the long run that raids are better, but you could always say "let's go one level deeper", at which point the depth limiting is moot because, by that logic, you should just search until you hit the very bottom.
  In short: follow the tie-breaking rules.

title: Raid without conquer
author: Nandan Paramashiva (anon. to classmates)
text: Since stake has a higher priority over raid, do we really need to include a 'raid without a conquer' state in the children's list? I remember reading in one of the discussion thread, where one of the TA had mentioned otherwise. So double checking on this.

followup.name: Thomas Collins
followup.text: Just to add on, there is no such thing as a raid without conquer. There are only stakes and raids. In some situations, raiding may take over opponents tiles, while in other situations, no such rules may be available. You could add tests that filter out actions that shouldn't be optimal, but I think it is easier conceptually just to consider all possible actions. But, if your program always outputs the correct answer, then it is correct.

replies.name: CHEN, CHI-AN
replies.text:
If I understand correctly:
I think what he meant is "If the player uses raid but there is no opponent's tiles around the raided tile, then it becomes raid without conquer"?

replies.name: Nandan Paramashiva (anon. to classmates)
replies.text:
Correct. That's what I meant.
So, the state we get by doing such raid would anyway be covered by doing a stake.

replies.name: Thomas Collins
replies.text: Right, I understand. Sorry if I wasn't being clear. What I was saying was, yes, in theory this should give you the correct answer, but if you consider all stake and raid actions, there is no harm. What I was saying was there are only two types of actions: stakes and raids. But, if there are no pieces to conquer, stakes and raids transition the player to the same resulting board state. So, in theory, considering stakes in such situations should be sufficient, but, to be safe, I still recommend searching all possible actions. There is no harm in doing so, and it will not add significant time to the execution. It seems to me that searching all possible actions is easier than selectively searching some in different cases, so I was just trying to say you don't have to do it this way. But, to Chi-An's point, if you have an easy way to do it, it should give you the correct answer.

replies.name: Nandan Paramashiva (anon. to classmates)
replies.text: Thank you !

title: Alpha-Beta Pruning: Tie-Breaking
author: Chanuwas Aswamenakul
text: According to the figure below, the raid move has been considered first, and then the alpha-beta pruning pruned one child node of the second branch, so the value at the min node is 3, which equals to the min node at the first branch. I want to confirm if, however, the first branch still should be picked. Also, when the algorithm considers the last branch, it will prune one child node of that branch as well. Nevertheless, the algorithm is supposed to pick the third branch as a result because of the tie-breaking condition. Am I correct? And how could this thing work out?

followup.name: Shreyas Singapura
followup.text: Shouldn't we search all stakes first and then, raid? If so, then we would never prune a stake branch with the same value as a raid branch.

replies.name: Chanuwas Aswamenakul
replies.text: Yeah, I just read the discussion on Piazza carefully again. I fixed it. Thanks anyway.

replies.name: Hannes Leipold (anon. to classmates)
replies.text: I think they're allowing people to give the answer of 2 because the iterative deepening protocol ignores the actual weights of the nodes and sets them equal to 1. If you look at the "actual cost" on the graph, however, it would be 13. Depending on how you interpreted the problem, i.e. return using the actual weights or the set weights from the algorithm, you would get one of these two answers.

replies.name: Om Patri
replies.text: Thank you.

followup.name: Ruoxuan Wang (anon. to classmates)
followup.text: There's no specific explanation in Q3 c) (iii). Why is it "No"? What's the meaning of "chance nodes"?

replies.name: Hannes Leipold (anon. to classmates)
replies.text: It's no because of the same reason as I), that is, alphabeta pruning IS NOT approximating so we know that the answer for a expectiminimax or minimax will be the same regardless of our usage of alphabeta pruning of any kind. If this were not so, alpha beta pruning would not always return the same answer as the simple minimax algorithm. The point is that expectations calculations don't actually change this algorithm paradigm.

title: Doubt regarding midterm1 Q4(c)
author: Qingfeng Du
text: When I ran arc-3 algorithm, I couldn't eliminate any of the domain values for binary constrains. But the answer saids AI/M should be in corner. If the answer is true, could someone give me a more detailed explanation of it? Thanks!

author: Tianfeng Ye (anon. to classmates)
student_answer.text: Try to start with the node with the fewest legal values. If node1 is arc consistent with respect to another node2, so for every value in the domain of node1, there is some value in the domain of node2 that satisfies the binary constraint on the arc connected node1 and node2.

followup.name: Qingfeng Du
followup.text:
I looked at the algorithm again and here's what I thought.
  Even for X2 or X5(the most constrained variables), for every domain value, there exist a possible value for the other nodes to satisfy the binary constrains, so I wouldn't eliminate any of the domain values. Same for other nodes. If you think there's a way you can find inconsistency, please provide a detailed example. Thanks.

replies.name: Tianfeng Ye (anon. to classmates)
replies.text:
Let us set X2 for AI, which means(X1, X3, X4, X5, X6) can not be assigned AI based on arc consistent, but you have one more AI left in domain, same with M.
Thus only DB and P can be assigned to the domain of X2.
X4 is symmetric with X2.

replies.name: Tianfeng Ye (anon. to classmates)
replies.text: Sorry, X5 is symmetric with X2.

replies.name: Hannes Leipold (anon. to classmates)
replies.text: X2 is the most constrained, but for every x in X2 there is an allowed y in it's neighbors, so without using paths or higher order "arcs", I don't think we can eliminate any options.

followup.name: Sachin Sharma (anon. to classmates)
followup.text:
I have the same question as Qingfeng Du. 
AC-3 can look at only 2 nodes at a time. In Q4, for every value of a node, there exist a legal value for each of its neighbors. So the domain values remain same for all nodes. The thing to be noticed here is only 2 nodes are looked at, at a time. So every pair of nodes are arc-consistent with each other. Could someone tell me what I am doing wrong?
  It would be better if one of the TA's answered the question.

followup.name: Chai Zheng Xin
followup.text: I think unless you use k consistency greater than 2 (arc), you would not be able to eliminate more values other than center nodes for M and AI

replies.name: Connor Zarecki
replies.text: I think I agree. Does anyone know why the corner tables (1,3,4,6) can't have DB and P in their domain?

followup.name: Om Patri
followup.text:
In the updated regrading, both answers are accepted. 
  i.e. it is okay if you do not eliminate any of the domain values, your answer will still be accepted.

title: Midterm 1 Regrade Requests
author: Om Patri
text:
Dear Students,
  If you want to request for a regrade on any of your midterm 1 answers, please read ahead.
  - First of all, please check the midterm 1 solutions and grading rubric I posted in the other note at @416
- Office hours are not for regrading, please do not ask any TAs for increasing your grades in the office hours, they will not do it.
- Do not email TAs or instructors about regrading, you will not get back a response. If you emailed already, you will still not get back a response.
- It is necessary that you know your Crowdmark paper number. This number can be found on the top right portion under the QR code and under "midterm1" beginning with a # and before the page number (e.g. 2 of 9). This number will be between 1 to 600. Your regrading request will not be accepted without referencing this Crowdmark paper number.
  - To request a regrade, please fill in the form (link below) before Thursday night (midnight), which is a little more than 48 hours from now. You will need to sign into your USC Google account to access this form, and it records your email address too. The form asks which question you are asking for a regrade on, from Q1 to Q6. If you have questions on multiple subparts, e.g. 3(a) and 3(c), mention them all in the justification text box. You can fill up the form again for a different question. Please keep your justification brief and to the point.
The link to the regrade request form is - Regrading Form Link
  - Most of the regrade requests we get every year are not accepted simply because the students do not read the solutions and rubric carefully or are overly optimistic with their partially correct solutions. For example, in this midterm, do not ask for a regrade if you have committed mistakes like the following - 
On Q2 - if you don't have the complete path sequence correct for a subpart, you will lose 6 points. For e.g. if the correct path is A-B-C-D-E-F-G-H-I, and you wrote A-B-C-D-E-G-H-I, you will lose all points for the path (for each subpart). There is no partial grading within that.
On Q5 - if you wrote "Yes" as the answer, which is wrong, you get a 0/10 and 2/3rds of the class has committed this error. Please don't ask for a regrade in this case. If you wrote "No" but failed to provide a correct counter example and fully justified explanation, the same thing holds.
  - We aim to complete all regrades by next Tuesday night. By then, you should see an additional comment "regraded" on your Crowdmark answers page (for whichever question you requested a regrade on), and your grade adjusted accordingly if there was an error earlier in grading.
  - Please don't post follow-up questions to this post to discuss your regrading issues (such questions will be deleted). You can use the regrading form to let us know if you have questions on your answers or alternative solutions to some questions which we may not have covered in the rubric. If there are still any lingering questions about this, you can email me.
  Cheers,
Om Patri
CS 561 TA
patri@usc.edu
#pin

title: about operator priority
author: Jialiang Mo
text:
What is operator priority?
I know that ()is the highest and ~ is the second highest.
Is the priority of => higher or lower than &?
Thank you!

author: Om Patri
Sruthi Madapoosi Ravi (anon. to classmates)
student_answer.text:
Highest to lowest
1. ()
2. not
3. and, or
4. => (implies)

followup.name: Mukund Mandyam Kannappan (anon. to classmates)
followup.text: So and, or is just evaluated left to right? since A | B & C can result in different values.

replies.name: Om Patri
replies.text: Edited my earlier post which had an error. Yes, they have different orders, the priority order goes NOT > AND > OR when no parentheses. Between two ORs the order doesn't matter (left to right).

replies.name: Mukund Mandyam Kannappan (anon. to classmates)
replies.text:
A is T, B is F and C is F
If AND is performed first its T
If OR is performed first its F

replies.name: Chun-Ning Chang (anon. to classmates)
replies.text: So, if A => B | C, we should perform as A => (B | C)?

replies.name: Vinod Sharma

followup.name: Om Patri
followup.text: I edited my previous answer above to correct it. And has a higher priority than Or.

replies.name: Chai Zheng Xin
replies.text: This is confirmed right? I am asking because according to standard FOL, & and or has same precedence.

replies.text: Yes, for the homework3.

title: Question about example 1 in HW3
author: Nguyen (Chris) Tran (anon. to classmates)
text:
I am trying to prove by hand the queries from example 1 of HW3 and have some questions.
  1/ I have a difficult time proving H(John) to be True
In order to prove H(John), I negate it to ~H(John) and try to find contradiction, but could not. Could anyone please give me some directions? 
  2/ I don't understand why G(Bob) is false
In order to prove G(Bob), I negate it to ~G(Bob).
Then use resolution inference to infer from (~F(x) V G(x)), I have ~F(Bob) which contradicts with given F(Bob). Therefore, G(Bob) must be True, but the solution states it is False.
    Thank you in advance

author: Mukund Mandyam Kannappan
student_answer.text:
This is because the sentences in KB itself are contradicting -
D(John,Bob)
D(x,y) => ~H(y)
G(x)=>H(x)
F(x)=>G(x)
F(Bob)
From the first two sentences we get ~H(Bob) (modus ponens)
From the third sentence we get ~G(Bob) (modus tollens)
And from the fourth we get ~F(Bob) (modus tollens)
And the fifth sentence is F(Bob) - this is a contradiction
So there is an error in the example which must be corrected.

title: Question about Translating English to FOL
author: Tianyu Fang (anon. to classmates)
text:
Consider this example in lecture notes, MW, session 11-12, P29
  "No purple mushroom is poisonous."
  You can translate it in two ways:
¬(∃ x) purple(x) ^ mushroom(x) ^ poisonous(x)   or, 
(∀ x) (mushroom(x) ^ purple(x)) => ¬poisonous(x) 
  But how about using ∃ with => or ∀ with ^? For example, can (∀ x) mushroom(x) ^ purple(x) ^ ¬poisonous(x)
stands for the statement above? Please clarify the differences between them, thanks.

followup.name: Tianyu Fang (anon. to classmates)
followup.text:
Thank you for your reply. However, with simply change of position of ¬, it seems that the FOL expressions may translate the English statement more closely, which are slightly different from two expressions listed above in my opinion. For example,
  ¬(∃ x) purple(x) ^ mushroom(x) => poisonous(x) means Not EVEN one purple mushroom implies it is poisonous
(∀ x) mushroom(x) ^ purple(x) ^ ¬poisonous(x) means To ALL situations, purple mushroom which is nontoxic is true
Could you please explain detailedly why these two logic expressions cannot translate statement above correctly? Thank you.

replies.name: Luenin
replies.text:
hi Tianyu,
  Again, the statements involve small and subtle distinctions that greatly affect the intended meaning.  So this statement:
  (∀ x) mushroom(x) ^ purple(x) ^ ¬poisonous(x)  means: "any x, is mushroom and is purple and is nonpoisonous"
  In other words, "All x are purple nonpoisonous mushrooms."  What if x is a banana? Would that statement be true?  Of course not.  What you want to say is for all x, IF x is a purple mushroom, THEN it is nonpoisonous.  That is expressed with the original statement:
  (∀ x) (mushroom(x) ^ purple(x)) => ¬poisonous(x)  which says "any x, if it is a mushroom and is purple, then it is not poisonous" In other words, "Purple mushrooms are not poisonous."
  Likewise for the first case which is a vacuous truth statement: "¬(∃ x) purple(x) ^ mushroom(x) => poisonous(x)" which means: "there is not some x, if it is purple and is a mushroom, then it is poisonous".  Fine, since x cannot be a purple mushroom, let x be a green tomato.  The statement is STILL true, which is NOT what we want.  Why is it true?  Because implications are still true when the antecedent is false, regardless of whether the consequent is true or not. 
    Remember, the statements we make must be true in the universe in which they take place.  The original statement:
  ¬(∃ x) purple(x) ^ mushroom(x) ^ poisonous(x) 
  captures accurately the expression we set out to make: "there is not some x, is purple and is a mushroom and is poisonous."  In other words, "No Purple mushrooms are poisonous"

replies.name: Tianyu Fang (anon. to classmates)
replies.text: Thank you very much, now it's all clear to me:)

title: Question about FOL
author: Wei Huang (anon. to classmates)
text:
"No person buys an expensive policy. "
The answer that was given on the side is 
∀x,y,z Person(x)∧Policy(y)∧Expensive(y) ⇒ ¬Buys(x,y,z)
  Why those valuables are all universal quantity? Why can't it be ∀x Person(x)∧(∃y Policy(y)∧Expensive(y) ⇒ ∃z ¬Buys(x,y,z)
  Thanks.

author: Om Patri
Jiayue Yang (anon. to classmates)
student_answer.text:
"an expensive policy" means every possible policy that is expenvice, so it should be universal quantifier.
But, if it is "∀x Person(x)∧(∃y Policy(y)∧Expensive(y) ⇒ ∃z ¬Buys(x,y,z)" , it means for all the people, they will not buy some certain expensive policies, which indicates they may buy some other policies that are expensive.

title: Query about nested predicates.
author: Ratan George Senapathy
text:
Suppose if I have a predicate IsEqual(x,y) which return true iff x equals y.
Now suppose there are predicates IsBoy(x) and IsGirl(x) which return true when x and y are boys and girls respectively.
Can a sentence like this be given in the KB for the homework?: 
IsEqual(IsBoy(John),IsGirl(Jill))
or will it be broken down in different sentences. I basically want to know whether there will be a predicate inside a predicate.

author: Om Patri
Chai Zheng Xin
student_answer.text:
That is not possible according  to FOL syntax.
Predicates can only contain terms.
A term can be a function, constant or variable.

title: Question about Translating English to FOL
author: Garrett Witowski (anon. to classmates)
Chun-Yuan Chen
text:
Can I make it like below?
Exist t time(t) => Vx person(x)^can-fool(x,t)
\exists t\ time(t) => \forall{x}\ person(x)\ \wedge \ canfool(x,t)

author: Chun-Yuan Chen
student_answer.text:
One follow up, For another English sentence.
Can I say either of these instead?
Vt time(t) => Exist p person(p) ^ can-fool(p,t)
Existp person(p) => Vt time(t) ^ can-fool(p,t)

followup.name: Shreyas Singapura
followup.text:
Vt time(t) => Exist p person(p) ^ can-fool(p,t)
means 2 persons fooled at 2 times need not be the same.
  Regarding other statements, I am not sure if using "exists" along with "implies" would serve the purpose. There will be multiple values of the variable used in "exists" which do not satisfy the "implies". Therefore, using "and" with "exists" would ensure the condition is satisfied for any number of variables. Hope this helps.

followup.name: Chun-Yuan Chen
followup.text:
Quote:
Vt time(t) => Exist p person(p) ^ can-fool(p,t)
means 2 persons fooled at 2 times need not be the same.
  May I ask how you conclude 2 persons need NOT be the SAME?

replies.name: Shreyas Singapura
replies.text:
It is because of the ordering of "for all" and "exists". 
  For the order, "exists" and then "for all", you are fixing a particular variable and then checking for all other variables. While checking variables of "for all", the variable in "exists" has to be the same. 
  For the order,  "for all" and then "exists", you fix a variable and check if there exists another variable. Then, repeat over variables of "for all". While repeating, the variable of "exists" need not be the same across iterations.

title: non-horn sentences and comparison among forward chaining, backward chaining and resolution
author: Chenguang Wang
text:
Hi,
  I have the following 2 questions.
  As I remember, it's said that a goal sentence can be proved by GMP iff its KB can be converted into several horn sentences. Therefore, can anyone show me a simple counter-example that its KB cannot be converted into horn sentences but the goal sentence can be proved by some other method(such as resolution)?
To my understanding, resolution can prove some sentences which forward chaining and backward chaining cannot prove. So what is the use of studying forward chaining or backward chaining if, I understand correctly, resolution has already covered all the functionalities that these 2 algorithms have?
  Thank you.

author: Chai Zheng Xin
student_answer.text:
KB:
A(x) or B(y)
Not A(John)

You want to prove B(Bob) so you try KB and not B(Bob). 

A(x) unifies with A(John) so you get B(y).
B(y) unifies with B(Bob) resulting in a contradiction. Therefore, B(Bob) is true. 

The above proof is by resolution. (A(x) or B(y)) has more than 1 positive literal so it is no horn.

followup.name: Chenguang Wang
followup.text:
Hey Chai,
  Good hit! I understand your process of resolution proving. But that's what I am thinking of and worried about. So take your KB as an example. If you allow me to equivalently transform it a little bit, let's say
  KB:
Not A(x)->B(x) (I think it's the same as "A(x) or B(x)" since "a v b <-> not a -> b")
Not A(John)
  (BTW, I use B(x) here instead of B(y) to make it has some relationship between the premise and the result. Otherwise we would be able to prove any personal name in B() is correct, such as B(Bob), B(Lebron), etc.)
  Let's say what we want to prove is still B(John). Can I apply modus pones law and unification here which acts like "Not A(x)->B(y), Not A(John)" implies "B(John)"? If so, then a KB with non-horn clauses could have been proved by modus pones.

replies.name: Chai Zheng Xin
replies.text: That's a good question. I would like to know too. I got a feeling it has something to do with closure under horn clauses. Resolving 2 horn clauses result in a horn clause and resolving a horn clause with a goal clause results in a goal clause.

title: Converting english to logic
author: Michelle (anon. to classmates)
text:
I had two questions on converting english to logic and logic to english
  1. In class we had the following sentence
        ∀ y ∃x Loves(x, y)
Which translated to:
   "Everyone in the world is loved by at least one person"
I was wondering if this would be equivalent to 
   "Everyone in the world loves at least one person"?
I thought the latter made more intuitive sense than what the slides show, but I just wanted to make sure they were both equivalent since Prof Itti defined Loves(lover, lovee). 
  2. I am a bit confused about when we should translate an english sentence using an existential quantifier instead of a universal symbol. For most examples in class we used a universal symbol, however the following sentences made me want to use existential symbol at first, since they had "one's" and "a" as adjectives:
"One's mother is one's sibling's mother" and " A first cousin is a child of a parent's sibling"
Which made me write the following translations at first:
∃ x,y,z sibling(x,y) ^ mother(z,x) ^ mother(z,y) , meaning x and y are sibling's with the same z mother. Could you please explain why this would be wrong? 
and same for the second sentence:
∃ x,y,w,z FirstCousin(x,y) ^ Parent(z,y) ^ Parent(w,x) ^sibling(w,z), meaning w z are siblings with children x,y whom are first cousins.
  Thank you!

author: Akshay Deshmukh (anon. to classmates)
student_answer.text:
I will divide my answer in 2 parts:
  1. Consider 2 sets: x \in {A, B, C} and y \in {P, Q, R}.
Now, the FOL sentence correctly translates to "Everyone in the world is loved by at least one person". This would mean that P is loved by B, Q is loved by B and R is loved by A. The interpretation satisfies the universal quantifier constraint on y, as given in the sentence, and the interpretation is considered to be correct.
Your interpretation is "Everyone in the world loves at least one person" which would mean that A loves P, B loves Q and C loves Q. In this case, the interpretation does not satisfy the universal quantifier constraint on y and the meaning has been altered as a consequence. In the given example, R is not loved by anyone and since R \in y, it should be loved by someone in accordance to the FOL statement.
  2. The given statements are general truths (only when blood relations are considered). Such facts hold in all circumstances and universal quantifiers need to be used. When an existential quantifier is used, there will always be a situation which will not conform with English interpretation.
For example, consider this FOL sentence: ∃ x,y,z sibling(x,y) ^ mother(z,x) ^ mother(z,y). Such a statement implies that there are cases where a sibling of a person may not have the same mother as that person. Such a case is not possible in reality (only blood relations) but the sentence implies that such a case can exist. Existential quantifiers imply searching through sets of positive and negative examples and returning a positive instance.
For the next case, consider this FOL sentence: ∃ x,y,w,z FirstCousin(x,y) ^ Parent(z,y) ^ Parent(w,x) ^sibling(w,z). Likewise, this statement implies that there are cases where a child's first cousin may not be the son/daughter of the person who is the sibling of the child's parent. Such a case is not possible in reality (only blood relations) but the sentence implies that such a case can exist.
Universal quantifiers cover all examples in the domain which is being examined. If there is an example which contradicts the universal statement, the statement fails for the entire set. Universal facts are expressed with a universal quantifier. In case of existential quantifiers, the English statement will contain words/phrases which imply a quantity (some, few, etc) which is lesser than the size of the universal set.

title: Are all these sentences equivalent?
author: Michelle
text:
English Sentence:
"You can fool all of the people some of the time"
  1. ∀x ∃t person(x) ^ time(t) => can_fool(x,t)
2. ∀x person(x) => ∃t ^ can_fool(x,t)
3. ∃t ∀x person(x) ^ time(t) => can_fool(x,t)

followup.name: Shreeharsha
followup.text:
But then in the slides, for sentence "You can fool some of the people all of the time" it is  ∃x ∀t  (person(x) ^ time(t)) ⇒ can-fool(x,t) that is existential operator is used with an implication.

In a similar way as above why not use  ∀x ∃t  (person(x) ^ time(t)) ⇒ can-fool(x,t) for sentence "You can fool all of the people some of the time".

replies.name: Garrett Witowski
replies.text: In these cases I believe it's okay to use the existential quantifier because of the way the phrase is structured. Generally speaking, however, existential quantification should be used with "and" and universal quantification should be used with implication.

title: Question on converting a sentence to FOL
author: Chirag Sanghvi (anon. to classmates)
text:
For the following sentence
  "Everyone who loves all animals is loved by someone"
can the FOL for this be:
  ∀x ∀y Animal(y) ^ Loves(x, y) ⇒ ∃z Loves(z, x)
In the discussion the answer for the above sentence was as below.I am confused why do we need to infer animal=>loves(x,y) instead of Anding them as we did above ?
  ∀x (∀y Animal(y) ⇒ Loves(x, y)) ⇒ ∃z  Loves(z, x)

author: Chai Zheng Xin
student_answer.text: If you use and, the sentence becomes everyone who lives in a universe where all objects in the universe are animals loved by him is loved by someone.

followup.name: Harpreet Kaur Randhawa (anon. to classmates)
followup.text: I don't think what you wrote is wrong. Your sentence reads for all animals y and for all x who love y are loved by some z.

replies.name: Chai Zheng Xin
replies.text: A problem occurs when there is a y which is not an animal, the first sentence will still be true because it reduces to for all x, false implies there exists a z that loves x. This is incorrect, we want only care about the case when y is an animal.

replies.name: Chirag Sanghvi (anon. to classmates)
replies.text:
I understand what you say. As we have the check Animal(y) ^ Loves(x,y), if y is not an animal won't the sentence return false instead of true, ignoring that case ?
  I really don't understand how these nested implies work and when to use them. Can any instructor shed some light on this ?

replies.name: Harpreet Kaur Randhawa (anon. to classmates)
replies.text: True. Even I don't understand it. I also feel if it is not an animal it should become false first hand.

replies.name: Garrett Witowski
replies.text: Think of it like this: The first sentence reads "if, for every x,y, y is an animal and x loves y then some z loves x."  The second sentence reads "if for every x, if for every y that is an animal then the particular x loves that y is true, then there exists some z that loves that x". It's kind of like a series of nested if statements. What it comes down to is the fact that you need to express the notion of someone who loves all animals and sentence 1 doesn't do that.

replies.name: Hannes Leipold
replies.text: In the first sentence I think the first part is always false in some models and therefore the implication always true. This is because if there exists any y in our domain that isn't an animal, then the first clause will be false, since not all y are animals. Then for all x in our model domain, the implication will be true. Clearly not what we want the expression to do.

title: Can we turn CNF to DNF and vice versa?
author: Chun-Yuan Chen
text:
A ^ (BVC) => A^B V A^C
A V (B^C) => AVB ^ AVC
  Are they both correct?

author: Chun-Yuan Chen (anon. to classmates)
student_answer.text: Teacher said we don't need to care about this!

followup.name: Chun-Yuan Chen
followup.text: So is it true it can convert both way?

replies.name: Hannes Leipold
replies.text:
One way to check is just to look at the truth table of two boolean functions. If they match on all inputs, they're literally the same.
In case 1:
000 => 0,0; 001 => 0,0; 010 => 0,0; 001 => 0,0; 011 => 0,0; 100 => 0,0; 101 => 1,1; 110 => 1,1; 111 => 1,1;  so they match
  In case 2:
000 => 0,0; 001 => 0,0; 010 => 0,0; 001 => 0,0; 011 => 1,1; 100 => 1,1; 101 => 1,1; 110 => 1,1; 111 => 1,1;  so they match
  So you can use them interchangeably. Otherwise, you can use inference rules to show that one infers the other and vice versa. From there, soundness of propositional logic shows them to imply one another.

followup.name: Chun-Yuan Chen
followup.text: So it can convert both ways. Thank you!

author: Thomas Collins
Shreyas Singapura
student_answer.text: Once you match y = G(x,x) in the first parameters, the second parameter matching implies y = G(A,B). Since y can take only one value, G(x,x) = G(A,B) which means x = A and x = B. This cannot happen.

title: FOL translation question
author: Qingfeng Du
text:
You can fool all of the people some of the time.
The answer is: "V x person(x) => E t time(t) ^ can-fool(x,t)
Can I do: E t V x person(x) ^ time(t) => can-fool(x,t) ?

followup.name: Garrett Witowski
followup.text: You can't do the second one because that reads "There exists a t for all x such that if x is a person and t is a time then x can be fooled at t." Translating that a little bit, we end up with: "There exists a time where all people can be be fooled at that time." That's not the same as "You can fool all of the people some of the time."

replies.name: Qingfeng Du
replies.text:
There exists a time where all people can be be fooled at that time.
=> All people can be fooled at some time
=> You can fool all of the people some of the time.
I don't see there's a conflict.

replies.name: Garrett Witowski
replies.text:
Basically, \forall{x}\ Person(x)\Rightarrow \exists{t} \ Time(t)\ \wedge \ CanFool(x,t) says that for each person there is some time when that person can be fooled. 
\exists{t}\ \forall{x}\ Person(x)\ \wedge \ Time(t)\Rightarrow CanFool(x,t) says that there is at least one time when you can fool all people. Meaning that then, and only then, can you fool every person.

replies.name: Qingfeng Du
replies.text: Oh, because time frame for one can be fooled is different from another one. That make sense. Thanks!

replies.name: Garrett Witowski
replies.text: No problem, glad I could help!

Converting into CNF, I get:
\varphi = 
eg	ext{Person(x))} \vee 
eg 	ext{Policy(y)} \vee 
eg 	ext{Expensive(y)} \vee 
eg 	ext{Buys(x,y,z)}
\psi =

title: Discussion-6(Ex 7.4)
author: Priyesh Lakar (anon. to classmates)

text:
(A ⇔ B) ⇔ C has the same number of models as (A ⇔ B) for any fixed set of proposition symbols that includes A, B, C
  Ans: True..
  How?

author: Hannes Leipold
student_answer.text:
We can easily count the number of models, that is essentially inputs where (A ⇔ B) ⇔ C will be true or (A ⇔ B) will be true.
  In case 1:
000 => 0, 
010 => 1, #ofmodels  = 1
100 => 1, #ofmodels  = 2
110 => 0,
  001 => 1, #ofmodels  = 3
011 => 0, 
101 => 0, 
111 => 1, #ofmodels  = 4
  In case 2:
000 => 1, #ofmodels  = 1
010 => 0, 
100 => 0,
110 => 1, #ofmodels  = 2
  001 => 1, #ofmodels  = 3
011 => 0, 
101 => 0,
111 => 1, #ofmodels  = 4
  So they have the same number of models, 4 (unless I made a mistake, it is 4:10 in the morning).

title: Q 7.4 in text book AIAMA
author: Shashank Shekhar
text:
Do we need to solve these by truth tables only? Is there any other method?
  Follow-up question : What exactly do we need to look at the truth table, I am little confused about which rows to consider and which to discard.
  Thanks in advance.

author: Hannes Leipold
student_answer.text:
I think by truth table would be the easiest, otherwise you could find a procedure for an inference  and use that \varphi \vdash \psi if and only if \varphi \models \psi for propositional logic (also for first order logic). 
  In general, for \varphi \models \psi you need to check that \psi is true when \varphi is true. If you look at your truth table, you can consider only those cases where \varphi is true and check that \psi is true, but not vice versa.
  If \varphi \equiv \psi then we know that \varphi \models \psi and \psi \models \varphi so you will need to check that for each \psi which is true \varphi is true and for any \psi which is false that \varphi is false. In other words, you have no choice but to look at all entries. If you think these statements are false however, you can just use one clever counterexample where the rule breaks to answer the question.
  If you want to prove satisfiability, you only need to find a clever instance where the truth assignment is true, but if you would like to disprove satisfiability, you would have to check that each value is false. 
  Note that this would be a totally different story for first order logic for formulas that use the forall operator.

title: SPExam 2015 Qts 6(1)
author: Suxin Li
text: I am not clear about the meaning of "literal"?

author: Mark Debord
Mingqi Gu
student_answer.text:
The answer is B.
  A literal is an 'atomic formula' or its compliment. You can think of a literal as something that inherently is true (positive literal) or false (negative literal). B is not inherently true or false because we do not know the values of either A or B, there is more 'propositional' structure to B ('and' operation on A,B) where there is no additional propositional structure to A,C,D.

Hi,

author: Chun-Ning Chang
student_answer.text: In session14-15 P.80, it standardizes variables at step 4. The same order as discussion.

followup.name: Hannes Leipold
followup.text: Step 8 and 9 are not about forming CNF, but decomposing the CNF into our KB. That is, let \varphi = \psi_{1} \wedge \psi_{2} \wedge \psi_{3} , where each \psi_{i} is a clause. Then it is clear that KB_{new} = KB_{old} \cup \{ \varphi \} = KB_{old} \cup \{ \psi_{1} \wedge \psi_{2} \wedge \psi_{3} \} = KB_{old} \cup \{\psi_{1}, \psi_{2}, \psi_{3}\} since \varphi \models \psi_{i} and \{ \psi_{1}, \psi_{2}, \psi_{3} \} \models \varphi .

Hello, I am not clear about the format of the sentences in homework3. Will it include sentences in the following format?
S(x) => S(S(x)) Do we need any Occur Checking?
P(x,z) => P(F(John),z)
P(x,z) => Q(F(y))
Q(z) =>~(L(y)=>F(x))
(((L(x)))=>(((((F(y)))))))
(L(x)=>Q(z))
Can we have a detailed lexical and syntax rule? Or can we have a list of all the possible formats?

followup.name: Yanbin (anon. to classmates)
followup.text: Are S(S(x)), P(F(John),z), Q(F(y)) recursive/nested predicates? And why the last one cannot appear in the KB?

replies.name: Om Patri
replies.text: The last one CAN appear in the KB. To clarify, by the last one, I mean (L(x)=>Q(z)). The others in the original question CANNOT appear in the KB. And yes, the examples you gave cannot appear as they have nested predicates.

replies.name: Ronald Salloum (anon. to classmates)
replies.text: Why Q(z) =>~(L(y)=>F(x)) cannot appear in the KB? Thanks.

replies.name: Nguyen (Chris) Tran (anon. to classmates)

I agree with Liang. When X player selects C4, B4 has to be occupied according to HW2's spec. Therefore, this move has to be a Raid.
I can't understand the situation where the move is called "Stake", but it satisfies all conditions to be a Raid.
If TA can clarify on why B4 would NOT be taken if C4 is played by X, I would be very interested in knowing the reason.

replies.name: Jaeho Lee (anon. to classmates)
replies.text: I have same issue.. C4 Raid have better result than C4 Stake

replies.name: Jinho Park (anon. to classmates)
replies.text:
I agree that the instructors posts in @292 made it pretty clear that Stake actions need to be evaluated before any Raid actions. 
However, it was not so clear that the program is expected to evalue all empty spaces as Stake first (even though the exact same action can also be a Raid) and then evaluate Raid actions. In other words, it was not clearly delivered to students, either by the written homework description nor by the instructors' feedbacks, that the program is expected to pick the best action between Stake and Raid on the same cell by trying both actions.
I believe that this rule (/grading criteria) needed to be clearly stated because this is a counter-intuitive notion. For example, in tic-tac-toe, players do not get to freely choose whether to flip the opponent's piece in the middle or not; it is done automatically by the rule, given the arrangement of pieces.

replies.name: Songyue Huang (anon. to classmates)
replies.text: Since they yield to the same result, why c4 raid can not get credit?

replies.name: Thomas Collins
replies.text: I spent many many hours answering questions on Piazza regarding this issue. I explicitly and consistently stated this policy a number of times. Several Piazza questions dealt exactly with this issue. And the test cases released beforehand also tested such cases. It is also in accordance with the homework specification which states that a stake can be performed at any open space. It is impossible for homework specifications to be perfectly unambiguous, which is why I spent so much time answering student questions regarding this issue.

replies.name: Jinho Park (anon. to classmates)
replies.text: @Thomas Collins Could you provide an instance of one of the "Piazza questions dealt exactly with this issue" for a reference?

replies.name: Thomas Collins

replies.name: Jinho Park (anon. to classmates)
replies.text:
@Thomas Collins. I see that this scenario was specifically mentioned @320. Thanks for the reference.
  The unfortunate fact is that I (and probably other people who did not passed test #15) had not chance to take a look @320. 
  I think that this point was not explicit in the pinned thread @292. It does not mention whether Stake and Raid are mutually exclusive on a single cell or not.
  Now I think that this discussion boils downs to (for myself only other students may have different opinions) ) following two points. (one major and one minor.)
1. whether it was a reasonable assumption to make (i.e. assuming Stake and Raid are mutually exclusive on a single cell). (major point)
2. whether students are expected to be aware of critical information mentioned in non-pinned threads. (minor point)
  Could you re-consider the grading criteria for #15 based on these points?

followup.text:
Hi, 
  For test case 38, I think the move (D3 Raid) and (B3 Raid) are both accepted. The player can get the same max value from these two. It just depends on which loop order(row or col) you chose.

replies.name: Elizabeth Staruk
replies.text: We gave strict instructions about the move orders in order to avoid ambiguities like this.

replies.name: Xiao Hu
replies.text: I think you just mentioned that from top-left to bottom right.

replies.name: Michelle (anon. to classmates)
replies.text: I also followed the guidelines and did left to right row order and then column wise bottom to top and still missed this test case. Could you please look into this?

replies.name: Xiao Hu
replies.text: @292 , you mentioned from top-left to bottom right , row by row. I think D3 is the correct answer for the tie breaking WITHIN Raid. (I know that you mentioned Stake FIRST, THEN Raid.)

replies.name: c. Lee (anon. to classmates)
replies.text: Same here

replies.name: Alfonso Castellanos (anon. to classmates)
replies.text: Having same issue. Got D3 raid.

replies.text: I just want to know why we use the same logic but we fail this test case although the final result is right. But our method passes all the other cases.

replies.name: Davut Deniz Yavuz (anon. to classmates)
replies.text: I have the same issue.

replies.name: Jiayue Yang (anon. to classmates)
replies.text: You should search for ‘.’ from left to right, top to bottom, and see whether grids nearby can stake the ‘.’ grid. You got the different answer, because you may search for every ‘X’, and there decide whether there is ‘.’ nearby it can stake.

replies.name: Michelle (anon. to classmates)
replies.text: I did not see this note that was added a few days before the deadline, I just looked at it now. Either way the new rules shouldn't have affected previous ordering implementations of neighbor checking (left, right, bottom, up) and the TA's said they just wanted to simplify it. Shouldn't both answers receive credit?  "We wanted to simplify the tie-breaking rules, which is why we changed from the original neighbor-ordering part. Sorry if that caused any confusion."

replies.name: Alfonso Castellanos (anon. to classmates)
replies.text: ^ I agree. I didn't see that note either, and it was in a followup discussion, not even in the instructor's note field where it should be.

replies.name: Alfonso Castellanos (anon. to classmates)
replies.text: Original post: "Search stake actions before raid actions, search the board in order (top left to bottom right, row by row), and search neighbors in the order left, right, down, up, follow the pseudocode, and you should get the correct answer." Although it was updated later, the explicit search order for neighbors suggested a search for player pieces capable of performing a raid because it doesn't make sense to have such an order if we're merely searching for empty spaces.

replies.name: Thomas Collins
replies.text: Correct, which is why we removed the neighbor ordering part. If you are searching through empty spaces, regardless of neighbor order, you will get the correct answer. If you are searching for Xs or Os first to find raid moves, you will end up with duplicate moves, which is why it's incorrect. And that note was not updated a few days before the deadline. As I recall, it was quite a while before. I modified the instructors answer to that post to be in accordance with the simplified rules as well. It wasn't just the follow up discussion. It your program searches through Xs and Os, it will add the same moves multiple times and will be out of the top left to bottom right ordering. We removed the neighbor ordering as it was not necessary. You still must follow the top left to bottom right ordering.

replies.name: Thomas Collins
replies.text: Also, B3 RAID comes before D3 Raid in the top left to bottom right ordering. Since D3 Raid, is not explicitly better, it is not chosen over B3 Raid. What answer does the grading script expect for that test case?

replies.name: Thomas Collins
replies.text: @322 is one example of a question that dealt precisely with this issue, by the way, and it was answered many days before the deadline.

replies.name: Michelle (anon. to classmates)
replies.text: The grading script expects B3 Raid for this test case. My implementation only updates moves that are strictly better than another move ( prioritizing stake moves), so only this test case is affected, as the prioritizing order is correct for all other test cases. It's just a matter of whether we are checking for an empty piece and seeing if we can raid there, or checking to see if we have another piece in which we can raid from. The example given in the instructions for the definition of Raid suggested this implementation, and with your original post: "Search stake actions before raid actions, search the board in order (top left to bottom right, row by row), and search neighbors in the order left, right, down, up, follow the pseudocode, and you should get the correct answer," I was reassured I could implement it that way. I did not see the new follow up discussions, as I'm sure many of missed.

replies.name: Thomas Collins
replies.text: Again, @322 dealt with this exact issue, about a week before the due date, and I updated the instructor answer for @292 two weeks (give or take) before. I will discuss this with the teaching staff and we will decide what to do about this test case. In my view, we gave ample warning about any potentially changed details. Again, this didn't change the homework assignment specifications, it is just that the ordering I suggested would lead to repeated states and may violate the top-left to bottom-right ordering. As soon as I realized this (again, I believe it was about two weeks before the due date, certainly not fewer than 7-8 days before the due date), I updated the answer. Other questions, such as @322 dealt precisely with this situation. The best I can offer is that the teaching staff will discuss this test case. Most likely, however, it will stay as is. But we do want to be fair and will discuss it amongst ourselves.

replies.name: Alfonso Castellanos (anon. to classmates)
replies.text: Thanks for the support Thomas. We value your constant, quality feedback. We understand where you're coming from. We just think that the penalty of -51% is harsh for having followed what were the rules at one point and for not having read through the followup discussions later.

replies.name: Thomas Collins
replies.text: And I understand where the students are coming from. Every test case is extremely important due to the grading scale. We are trying our utmost to be fair about things. I will keep you all posted.

replies.name: Michelle (anon. to classmates)
replies.text: Thank you TJ. I appreciate you looking into this. I know you spent a long time answering all of our questions and clarifying things. I think it was just an unfortunate scenario that played out. Thanks again for looking into this!

replies.name: Xiao Hu
replies.text:
Hi Thomas,
  Thank you for your reply firstly!
Yes, with your way B3 is the answer.
But sorry, I'm not totally agree with you. It's just because we can use different tricks on our code. I used an array visited[row][col] to avoid duplicated moves on grid(row,col)[if it was visited, then don't need to visit again]. Because you mentioned that Stake first and then Raid separatelly, I think that the first idea comes to most of students when saw this requirement is to loop over Stake(empty space) first from top-left to bottom-right, and then Raid('X' or 'O') from top-left to bottom-right. Maybe your solution is the better way to avoid duplication, but it's not the ONLY way. It's not FAIR and WISE to say something is definitely wrong!
Also, I think this(the way we use) already involved in the implementation details. It should not be discussed. We are supposed to finish our HW individually.
  Finally, some suggestions for your reference:
1. There is no any official document(lecture slide, HW description) mentioned that all of the things discussed on Piazza are also the REQUIREMENT for HW. It's just mentioned Piazza is a good way to discuss our questions about this course.
  2. I really appreciate the lots of time you guys spend to answer students' questions. But, how to make the time you spend on Piazza more MEANINGFUL?
  Posting a summary for all of additional requirements discussed on Piazza as [Instr Note] to notify every student before deadline(like one week before). [Also it can avoid repeated answers and some similar question]
  Rather than hoping that all of students would go through all of materials discussed on Piazza. It's impossible for a student who already finished the HW and is overwhelmed by some other HWs on other courses to go through all of posts and discussions before deadline. We are not taking only one class and we are not supposed to know EVERY student's questions. Just like my followup on this topic, I don't think all of students would go through what I said here except some of students who may have same question with me. You mentioned that you modified the instructors answer to that post, maybe only you know that. Students seldom review the posts they saw already. 
The HW requirement was keeping changing even though time is close to deadline. It's highly possible that we missed something especially when time is close to deadline and we already finished it.
  Hope you can consider about that! I mean it! Thank you!

replies.name: Alfonso Castellanos (anon. to classmates)
replies.text: ^Yes, there should be a pinned post that is updated as relevant details of the assignment are fleshed out. Otherwise, they are lost in the dark abyss of Piazza!

replies.name: Jiayue Yang (anon. to classmates)
replies.text:
@Xiao Hu
Those students who got the right answers for HW2 spent hours looking into Piazza when they found there may be some tricks in HW2.
You didn't realize there must need some tie-breaking rules when you write your code, so from the very beginning, your algorithm has some flaws and is not complete.
Or maybe you realize there need some tie-breaking rules, but you are impatient to search through Piazza.

replies.name: Alfonso Castellanos (anon. to classmates)
replies.text: There shouldn't be any "tricks". The requirements should be more-or-less the same. Not having the time to search through Piazza is different than being too impatient. And it isn't from the "very beginning". These ordering rules were not specified in the requirements from the "very beginning".

replies.name: Thomas Collins
replies.text: The ordering rules were a necessity as the specification itself did not mention them. They were announced very near the beginning of the assignment time window. The only change that was made was to eliminate the explicit ordering of neighbors, as it may cause a conflict with the top left to bottom right principle. Since most students (by a large majority) had not seen that post before it was changed, the decision was made not to blast an email as that may potentially cause more confusion. We carefully consider such decisions. We did pin that corrected post (leaving the discussion about the change at the bottom). There is no trick involved. In my opinion, sufficient notice of any alterations were given. No changes were made. If we didn't specify a tie-breaking rule, it would have caused more confusion during grading. Students are responsible for the information on Piazza just as they would be an email blast. This issue was not just discussed in @292. At any rate, i will discuss with the teaching staff and keep you updated. If something changes, we will keep you posted.

replies.name: Guanyu Lu (anon. to classmates)
replies.text: Same issue for test case 38. From the post you gave "Search stake actions before raid actions, search the board in order (top left to bottom right, row by row), and search neighbors in the order left, right, down, up, follow the pseudocode, and you should get the correct answer" I don't think it means we shouldn't search Xs or Os first for Raid moves. For duplicate moves we can just simply maintain a table to check if the move has been evaluated, and I think for sparse playboards this search strategy should be more efficient rather than searching '.' first for Raid moves.

text:

Even we need to check stack before raid but in this case raid can definitely give us better result than stack so why should we choose stack instead of raid?

ALPHABETA
X
4
4 4 4 4
4 4 4 4
4 4 4 4
4 4 4 4
O..X
O..X
O..X
OO.X
Correct output:
C4 Stake
O..X
O..X
O..X
OOXX
Content from your output file:
C4 Raid
O..X
O..X
O..X
OXXX
test case not passed!

author: Thomas Collins
Avinash Venugopal (anon. to classmates)
student_answer.text:
Hi,

The depth given is 4. So when we compute the value after 4 steps, max value we get is -4. Both C4 Stake and C4 Raid return the same value (-4), According to the implementation mentioned, we consider all Stake moves first and then Raid and since C4 Raid doesn't give us a STRICTLY GREATER value, we go with C4 Stake

O..X
O..X
O..X
OOXX

title: Will there be multiple constant arguments in query?
author: Vinod Sharma

title: Standardize Variables (Renaming variable in local scope)
author: Pratik Shrikant Kabara (anon. to classmates)
text:
As mentioned in HW3 as all variables are universally quantified, how we will get to know which variable are local one? will brackets are helpful in this case?
  In normal first order logic, we were doing renaming based on existential and universal quantifier parenthesis and boundaries. But here all variable are universally quantified on the extreme left then how variable conflict case will arise?
  After CNF conversion we may require renaming of variables. But will renaming require before CNF conversion?
  Maybe I am missing something. Can you please give me example case where we need to rename variable before CNF conversion?

author: Chai Zheng Xin
student_answer.text:
I assume that for each sentence, all variables have scopes that extend to the whole sentence.
  You definitely need to standardize. Look at this case:
Clause 1: A(x,y) | ~B(y)
Clause 2: C(x) | B(x)
  Without standardization and directly resolving them would give A(x,x) | C(x) with theta = {y/x}, assuming you substitute into clause 1.
This is wrong because you lost the information that first and second terms of predicate A does not have to be same.
  However with standardization, you get:
  Clause 1: A(m,n) | ~B(n)
Clause 2: C(x) | B(x)
Then resolving them you get A(m,x) | C(x) with theta = {n/x}. This is what you want.

followup.name: Pratik Shrikant Kabara (anon. to classmates)
followup.text: So no need to rename variable before CNF, is that right?

replies.name: Bojun Huang
replies.text: Renaming is something neither before nor after CNF; instead, it is one step DURING CNF. Please see my answer above.

followup.name: Yanbin
followup.text: To solve the problem above, we can set different namespaces for each sentence. Thus, we don't have to standardize the variable.

title: Concept of k-fold cross validation
author: ANUSHA BILAKANTI (anon. to classmates)
text:
Concept of  k-fold cross validation explained in class is different from that mentioned in Wikipedia.
    Can anyone throw some light on what is k-fold cross validation?

author: Sriram
student_answer.text:
Given a labeled dataset, you perform k-fold cross validation in this way.

1. You need to split the data into K parts. Take one part as a validation set and remaining k-1 parts for training the classifier.

2. You test for precision and recall of your training by testing to predict the values of the validation set.

3. You have K different options to choose as a validation set. One way people generally follow is to choose each of the set as validation every iteration, and run for K iterations and finally take an average on the accuracy measures.

Basically validation set is hidden from training and the algorithm is expected to predict the classes of every input in the validation set correctly.

Some important things to consider before cross validation is that,

1. You randomize the data enough before you split it. This is to ensure the validation set doesn't contain something entirely new, which is not seen in training.

2. The choice of K can be ranging from 2 to N, with N as the number of data points. For datasets of size 1000, it is generally preferred to have 80-20% split between any training and validation sets. In this case k turns out to be 5.

The choice of K is subjective, empirically chosen and dependent on the data. Values of k=5 to 10 are generally used.

title: is new corrected input / ouput are right?
author: Pratik Shrikant Kabara (anon. to classmates)
text:
6
F(Bob)
H(John)
~H(Alice) =>False
~H(John) => True
G(Bob)
G(Tom)
14
A(x) => H(x)
D(x,y) => ~H(y)
B(x,y) ^ C(x,y) => A(x)
B(John,Alice)
B(John,Bob)
D(x,y) ^ Q(y) => C(x,y)
D(John,Alice)
Q(Bob)
D(John,Bob)
F(x) => G(x)
G(x) => H(x)
H(x) => F(x)
R(x) => H(x)
R(Tom)
    FALSE
TRUE
TRUE
FALSE
FALSE
TRUE
    can anyone please confirm on this?

author: Mun Kit Teh (anon. to classmates)
student_answer.text:
Yes it is correct.
  By resolution, to prove ~H(Alice) first negate the query to get H(Alice)
  The rule D(x,y) => ~H(y) in CNF is ~D(x,y) | ~H(y)
  Using resolution on ~D(x,y) | ~H(y) and H(Alice) by unifying {y/Alice}, we get ~D(x,Alice)
Then, by unifying ~D(x,Alice) and D(John,Alice) with {x/John} we can reach a contradiction.
  As for ~H(John), since H(John) is proven, ~H(John) cannot be TRUE.
  Correct me if I am wrong...

title: Confusion with example 1
author: Chai Zheng Xin
text:
For example 1, there are 3 rules:
(1) F(x) => G(x) 
(2) G(x) => H(x)
(3) H(x) => F(x)
  After converting to CNF, I get:
(4) ~F(x) v G(x)
(5) ~G(x) v H(x)
(6)~H(x) v F(x)
  Resolving (4) and (5), I get:
(7)~F(x) v H(x)
  Resolving (6) and (7), I get the empty clause, a contradiction.
This means any query is provable by this knowledge base.

followup.name: Jonathan Gan (anon. to classmates)
followup.text:
I think you can only resolve one pair of literals at a time because you have to ensure that they unify. So resolving 6 and 7, you would choose either

F(x) and ~F(x)
or
H(x) and ~H(x)

So the resolvent would be either

~H(x) v H(x)
or
~F(x) v F(x)

instead of the empty clause.

6 and 7 mean that one of ~H(x) and F(x) needs to be true and one of ~F(x) and H(x) needs to be true. So it is possible to have a world in which, for instance, F(x) is true and H(x) is true, which wouldn't be a contradiction.

replies.name: Chai Zheng Xin
replies.text: Thanks. I understand now.

title: What does True and False literal means in Knowledge base?
author: Pratik Shrikant Kabara (anon. to classmates)
text:
Can below statement appear in test cases?
  Man(x) & True -> Human(x)      ====  ~Man(x) | False | Human(x)
Man(x) | True -> Human(x)      ====  (~Man(x) | Human(x) ) & (False | Human(x)
Man(x) -> True         ====  (~Man(x) | True )

Man(x) & False -> Human(x)     ====  ~Man(x) | True | Human(x)
Man(x) | False -> Human(x)     ====  (~Man(x) | Human(x) ) & (True | Human(x)
Man(x) -> False         ====  (~Man(x) | False )
  What is meaning of these statements ? How to resolve them? 
False can be resolved by always putting True in KB and by negation cancelled out with False.
How to resolve True because we cannot put False in KB.
Can you please explain me step by step details?

title: IMPORTANT - HW 3 Clarifications
author: Elizabeth Staruk
text:
Homework deadline extended to 30th Nov

We have decided to modify the scope of the homework slightly to make parsing easier for students. 
  Any further future updates will be reflected as edits on this post (this is a live document for HW 3 clarifications).
  Please make sure that you visit this post first whenever there is a confusion.
    Any operator and its operands will always be surrounded by a parenthesis. Parenthesis will only appear in test cases when there is an operator with an operand or operands. So you don't have to worry about operator priority and parentheses confusions now.
For example:
(A(x) & B(x)) Valid
A(x) & B(x) InValid
((A(x) & B(x)) => C(x)) Valid
(A(x) | B(x)) => C(x) InValid
(~A(x)) Valid
~A(x) InValid
(A(x)) InValid
A(x) Valid
~~~~A(x) InValid
(~(~(~(~A(x))))) Valid
No nested Predicates.
For example:
A(x,y) Valid
A(B(x), y) InValid

No TRUE, FALSE,True,False literals in the homework

'=', '<=>' operators are not valid in the homework.

There can be spaces anywhere in the sentences and your code should handle them. You can do appropriate pre processing.

Query does not follow parentheses restrictions And remains as described in the homework.

Please ask any further questions separately as its own question on Piazza - not as follow ups to this post. Any follow ups to this post will be deleted.
    #pin

title: How to convert (A&(B|C)|D) into CNF (Distributive property)
author: Sunil Muralidhara (anon. to classmates)
text:
The lecture slide session (14-15) (Slide. 78, 7th point) tell us to distribute & over |. But if we have | over &, how are we supposed to convert to CNF?
  (A & (B | C)) | D
When distributive property applied this becomes
(A & B) | (A & C) | D
This is not in CNF. Looks like we have to introduce some new predicates to convert these as per the Wikipedia. Can you, please tell us how to handle these cases? Or can we assume that this kind of test cases do not appear?

author: Sriram
student_answer.text:
I think it should be ((A | D) & ((B | C) | D))
  Reduce it into simpler steps:
  (A & (B | C)) | D
= (A & beta) | D, where beta = (B | C)
= (A | D) & (beta | D)
= (A | D) & ((B | C) | D)
=(A | D) & (B | C | D)

You always distribute AND over OR. you keep A & (B|C) as is, as given above.

followup.name: Nandan Paramashiva (anon. to classmates)
followup.text:
If you meant (A&(B|C))|D
Then CNF would be
(A|D) &
(B|C|D)

If you meant A&((B|C)|D)
Then CNF would be
A &
(B|C|D)

Correct me If I am wrong

replies.name: Sriram
replies.text: You are right.

title: Can the resolution algorithm return true despite no constants?
author: Alfonso Castellanos (anon. to classmates)
text:
Consider the following example.
  Query: A(y)
KB: A(x)
  Step 1: Negate query and add to KB.
             KB: A(x), ~A(y)
  Step 2: Apply resolution to both clauses and use {x/y} as the substitution for A(x), resulting in an empty theta.
  Would this return true? All of the examples I've seen have always involved constants -- at least in the final step of the resolution algorithm.

author: Shubham Joshi
student_answer.text: All variables are assumed to be universally qualified. So for all x, A(x) is true. Consequently, A(y) is true even if you don't know what y is.

title: CNF in KB
author: Connor Zarecki
text:
For a CNF sentence like (A(y) | B(y)) & (C(x) | D(x) | E(x)), could it be represented in the KB as two different sentences:
1. (A(y) | B(y))
2. (C(x) | D(x) | E(x))
or should they stay anded together?
Basically, is a KB with a single sentence (A(y) | B(y)) & (C(x) | D(x) | E(x)) logically equivalent to a KB with two sentences of (A(y) | B(y)) being one and (C(x) | D(x) | E(x)) being the other?
Or does it all matter on what the variables are? For example what if the original sentence was (A(x) | B(x)) & (C(x) | D(x) | E(x))?

author: Adarsh Rajanikanth (anon. to classmates)
student_answer.text:
I am not sure if i have understood your question correctly. According to my understanding, the question is "If the sentence should stay as 1 sentence or 2 sentence",
then below is the answer.

I think it should stay as 2 sentences in KB.
Lets see how it works step by step:
1. We try to remove implication ----(No implication found, hence sentence stays as it is)
2. Push the negation inside ----(No negation found, hence the sentence stays as it is)
3. Distribute & over |----(In this step, we split the above sentence into two and put each of them into KB separately)

If we don't put it as 2 sentence, then I don't think it will be of any help in doing resolution.

Correct me if you think otherwise.

followup.name: Shubham Joshi (anon. to classmates)
followup.text: From page four of the spec, they should be two separate lines in your KB

title: Homework 2 Grading
author: Thomas Collins
text:
Hello students,

We apologize for the delay in grading homework 2. The grades should be available very, very soon. After discussing amongst ourselves, we have decided to eliminate test case 15 from homework 2, as it caused confusion. A number of students felt that the rules leading to getting it correct were unclear. So, homework 2 will consist of 49 test cases, and everyone will receive one free point. The total will still be out of 100 as with homework 1.

Namely, I would expect that all test cases need to be reevaluated with consideration for the "mutually exclusive Stake/Raid" interpretation.  This is because the interpretation actually rules out certain move possibilities.  Therefore, it would likely affect more than just the case(s) where cell ID agreed, but move type disagreed.
