Test case 38 was a different issue, not having to do with stakes and raids but rather tie breaking among raid actions. 

Test case 15 was the only test case that dealt with the issue of tie-breaking between stake and raid where the correct answer was not to raid. Many students were confused by this particular edge case and we felt it warranted removal. I will relay your concerns to the other teaching staff and we will update you with any changes.

title: Distributivity in CNF algorithm.
author: Kaushal Shah (anon. to classmates)
text:
According to the CNF algorithm given in slides of session 14-15, the last step is to distribute AND over OR.
  How would the following be solved?
  ( (A(x) & (B(x) | C(x))) | D(x) )

author: Chai Zheng Xin
student_answer.text:
Firstly, I think you mean distribute OR over AND.
  ( (A(x) & (B(x) | C(x))) | D(x) )
= (A(x) | D(x)) & ((B(x) | C(x)) | D(x))
= (A(x) | D(x)) & (B(x) | C(x) | D(x))
  The trick is to recognize that in the basic distributivity law,
(A & B) | C = (A | C) & (B | C)
  A, B and C can all be complex expressions.

followup.name: Sitong Ge (anon. to classmates)
followup.text: I treat A(x) as P and (B(x)|C(x)) as Q, D(x) as R, and I get ((A(x)|D(x))&(B(x)|C(x)|D(x)))

followup.name: Kaushal Shah (anon. to classmates)
followup.text:
Your answer is what we get intuitively.
The last step of algorithm clearly states distribute AND over OR.
(A & B) | C = (A | C) & (B | C) is true.
I need answer for
  ((A & (B|C)) | D)

replies.name: Chai Zheng Xin
replies.text:
Based on the Tuesday's session 14-15 lecture slide, the last step is distribute OR over AND. This also makes sense, given that you want CNF, which means conjunction should be the top level.
  I have given the steps for solving ((A & (B|C)) | D) above.

replies.name: Kaushal Shah (anon. to classmates)
replies.text: Got it. Thanks!

followup.name: Parul Priya (anon. to classmates)
followup.text:

  (~B(x,y)&~C(x,y))|A(x)|D(x,y)|Q(y)|E(x,y)

Will it be :
  (~B(x,y)|A(x)|D(x,y)|Q(y)|E(x,y)) &(~C(x,y)|A(x)|D(x,y)|Q(y)|E(x,y))

title: Factoring in FOL resolution
author: James Webb
text:
Page 347 of Russell + Norvig says that binary resolution is only refutation-complete when paired with factoring (i.e. removing redundant literals in each clause). Redundancy is not as obvious in FOL as it is in PL. For example in the PL clause (A | A), the second 'A' is clearly redundant, thus we can reduce to simply (A). However, what constitutes a redundant literal in FOL? Clearly we wouldn't want to factor something like (F(John) | F(James)), but it seems like we would want to factor (F(x1) | F(x1)). What about (F(x1) | F(x2))?
  More broadly, is factoring even a good idea for HW3 when building our resolution algorithm? Or would that be just asking for much more trouble than it's worth? Should we just stick with resolution of subsets (i.e. n-ary resolution)?
  Thanks for the clarification!

author: Chai Zheng Xin
student_answer.text:
I think we need to factor. From what I think, factoring works by reducing a pair of unifiable literals. Factor(F(John) | F(James)) is still F(John) | F(James) because F(John) cannot unify with F(James). However. Factor(F(x1) | F(x1)) is F(x1) because F(x1) is unifiable with F(x1). Factor(F(x1) | F(x2)) because F(x1) unifies with F(x2) and the result can be F(x1) or F(x2), depending on your substitution.
  Without factoring, it might be possible your clauses get longer and longer without convergence.

followup.name: tharangini anandan (anon. to classmates)
followup.text: So if we have F(x,y)|F(x,john)|B(y). Do we have to factor it to F(x,john)|B(john) ?

replies.name: Chai Zheng Xin
replies.text: I think so.

replies.name: Xinyu Feng (anon. to classmates)
replies.text: But if F(x,y)|F(A, B)|G(x,y)|G(C,D)?  Can there be two version of factoring?

replies.name: Chai Zheng Xin
replies.text: Refer to @686. That's what I did.

text:
Should we unify clauses even if there aren't any constants, and just variables.

H(x) | ~G(x,y)

author: Chai Zheng Xin
Mingqi Gu
student_answer.text:
same question!
  When talking about resolution, unification is normally done on the predicate level.
For the first example, you missed a step when which is standardizing apart the 2 clauses. Doing so, you should get.
~H(y) | ~D(x,y)
H(a) | ~G(a,b)
Then, Unify(~H(y), H(a)) returns theta={y:a} and using this substitution and cancelling the 2 predicates out, you will get a new clause, ~D(x,a) | ~G(a,b).

title: Does have factoring have to be recursive?
author: Chai Zheng Xin
text:
I read the binary resolution has to be paired with factoring to make resolution refutation complete.
  I am wondering whether factoring has to be recursive, consider factoring on this clause:
B(y) | B(John) | A(y) | A(John) | A(Sam)
  Factoring that recursively means there might be 2 depth first paths:
Path a
step 1a : B(John) | A(John) | A(John) | A(Sam) (due to factoring B(y) and B(John))
step 2a : B(John) | A(John) | A(Sam) (due to factoring A(John) and A(John))
  Path b
Step 1b: B(Sam) | B(John) | A(Sam) | A(John) (due to factoring  A(y) and A(Sam))
  So recursive factoring will result in the set {B(John) | A(John) | A(Sam), B(Sam) | B(John) | A(Sam) | A(John)}
  Or should we just do 1 level factoring, which means just cancel very pair of complementary literals without recursively factoring the results?
This would mean a clause for each cancellation

title: UNIFY-VAR
author: Guoxing Jin (anon. to classmates)
text: Can anyone tell me what val is in UNIFY-VAR function ?

author: Chai Zheng Xin
student_answer.text:
http://cs.stackexchange.com/questions/35280/can-someone-clarify-this-unification-algorithm
  val is the already substituted string for the current argument (if present)
  What Unify-Var is doing is to check if there are any existing bindings for the left expression or the right expression. If not, then it will bind the left expression to the right expression. This ensures that Unify-Var always returns the most general unifier for 2 terms.

title: Duplicate Sentences in KB
author: Kailash Singh Maurya (anon. to classmates)
text:
If I already have a clause in Knowledge Base of the form:
  ~P(a,b) | Q(b,c) | R(a,c)
  and If during resolution I infered a new statement of the form:
  ~P(x,y) | Q(y,z) | R(x,z)
(Just the variable names different due to standardisation)
  Are both the clauses equivalent ? and should the Knowledge Base have both the clauses or only one ?

author: Om Patri
Chai Zheng Xin
student_answer.text:
Yes, they are equivalent or strictly speaking ~P(a,b) | Q(b,c) | R(a,c) subsumes ~P(x,y) | Q(y,z) | R(x,z). Therefore you should not add ~P(x,y) | Q(y,z) | R(x,z) in.
In fact, there are multiple types of subsumption. ~P(a,b) subsumes ~P(a,b) | Q(b,c) | R(a,c), so do Q(b, c) and R(a,c). Generally, you do not want to insert clauses whereby there already exists a clause in that KB that has less restraint on terms or is shorter.

title: Unification doubt
author: tharangini anandan (anon. to classmates)
text:
In the below case how do we unify or is not unifiable?
It can be B(John,Bob) or B(Bob,John) depending on the order.
  A(x,John,z,p)|A(John,x,p,z)|B(z,p)
~A(m,n,John,Bob)
    Thanks!

author: Sriram
student_answer.text:
Your example doesn't seem to be in FOL. Consider the following
  <<THIS IS A WRONG KB>>
A(x,y,John) | A(John, x, y) | B(x, John)
~A(m,n, Bob)
<<END OF WRONG KB>>
  When we write A(x,y,John) 
First parameter               x: type1
Second parameter          y:type2
third parameter               john:literal
  We have established x to be of type1 and y to be of type 2. 
The second term in the sentence A(John, x, y) - We can't use x as a second argument because A takes "type2" as the second argument and x is of "type1". Same is the case with y.
  Since there is no quantifier in the sentence We have to assume that the variables are "universally quantified" we can't interchange the variables in the sentence. You have assumed z and p to be of strings and interchanged them, which is true only for this KB, and cannot be generalized.
  If you assume your sentence as, (changes marked in bold)
  1: A(x,John,z,p)|A(John,y,z,p)|B(z,p)
2: ~A(m,n,John,Bob)
  you will have to resolve it twice giving the following sentences
3: A(John, n, John, Bob) | B(John, Bob) - resolving with the first predicate sentence 1
4: A(x, John, John, Bob) | B(John, Bob) - resolving with the second predicate of sentence 1.
  Predicate B will always have (John, Bob).

title: Confusion on splitting sentences that contain AND operators.
author: Xi Chen (anon. to classmates)
text: If we split the A(x) & B(x) into two sentences A(x), B(x). After we resolve A(x) with ~A(John), do we also need to update B(x) to B(John), or leave it as B(x)? In other word, are A(x) and B(x) in A(x) & B(x) share the same scope or they are actually A(x1) and B(x2)?

author: Pratik Shrikant Kabara (anon. to classmates)
student_answer.text:
B(John)
Same scope!

followup.name: Xi Chen (anon. to classmates)
followup.text: If they are in the same scope, why do we need to split it into two sentences? I think it is more convenient to leave it as A(x) & B(x)...

replies.name: Pratik Shrikant Kabara (anon. to classmates)
replies.text: But you need to resolve both of them somehow. Splitting is a good option otherwise, you can achieve the same thing in multiple ways.

replies.name: Sriram
replies.text: One way to put it is that resolution rule works on clauses. Clause is defined as disjunction (ORs) of literals. The literals here are predicates like A(x,y) or B(z). you have to split conjunctions into clauses.

title: Confusion about π(t) of HMM
author: Chai Zheng Xin
text: Why is π(t) of HMM quantified as a probability? I understand that π(t) is the probability distribution of the current model state at time t. If t > 0, wouldn't the model state be influenced by the agent's actions? If that is the case, why would it be probabilistic?

followup.name: Chai Zheng Xin
followup.text: It is in slide 15 of 24-Utility-Policy-POMDP.pdf. The section is Hidden Markov Model (2/2).

replies.name: Thomas Collins
replies.text:
Thank you for the slide number.
π(t)
is the probability of being in some state at time t. We quantify this as a probability distribution because we don't know the original state (at time 0) for certain, meaning that we don't know the state for sure even if the agent's actions are deterministic. Also, the agent's actions themselves may be nondeterministic, meaning that the state resulting from taking an action given a current state is not known for sure, even if the states are fully observable. In general, we have to deal with both uncertainty in the agent's motion (nondeterminstic actions) and uncertainty regarding the state the agent is in (states are not fully observable). This is why we use the tools of probability theory to  model the state at each time t.

replies.name: Chai Zheng Xin
replies.text: Based on your explanation, it seems to imply that HMM is not operating on the perspective of the agent because if it is, the agent will definitely know its own actions.

replies.name: Thomas Collins
replies.text:
The agent will know the actions it took, but it will not necessarily know the results of those actions. Unknown walls may block the agents path, for instance. Or, as in the case of a wheeled robot, for instance, the agent's actuators may be noisy mechanisms. There is a difference between the actions that an agent takes (which it knows for certain) and the states resulting from those actions (often not known for certain).
  For example, imagine a wheeled robot that moves North, South, East, and West. It moves by turning in the appropriate direction and moving forward for 5 seconds. Its state is its 2D position. The robot will know which action it has taken (N, S, E, W), but it may not know the result of those actions if its actuators are noisy. The robot may go forward 8 cm sometimes, 12 cm other times, 9 cm sometimes, etc. Therefore the result of the action is not knowable for certain and thus the state resulting from that action (which depends on the distance the robot travels forward) is non-deterministic.

replies.name: Chai Zheng Xin
replies.text: I understand now why  π is a probability distribution. I have 1 more question, does it mean  π vary based on different policies the agent takes? For example, an agent that intends to move South in time t should still have a higher probability of reaching South in time t even if it is not guaranteed due to possible obstacles.

replies.name: Thomas Collins
replies.text: If we assume that the agent has a reasonable motion model (i.e., not completely random), then, yes, it is more likely that the agent will move into certain states than others depending on which actions were taken. For example, the agent may move South with probability 0.9 if the action taken is S, with the remaining 0.1 probability split uniformly amongst the other possible states.

replies.name: Chai Zheng Xin
replies.text: Ok thanks.

title: Renaming Variables
author: Ronald Salloum (anon. to classmates)
text:
From what I understand, when resolving two clauses, we are suppose to rename one of the clauses so that the same variable doesn't appear in both clauses. For the following example, I am wondering what is the proper way to do the renaming.
  Suppose we had these two clauses: P(x) | R(z)  and  ~P(y) | Q(z). We would be resolving P(x) and ~P(y), which do not share the same variable name (so no renaming required for them). Do I still need to rename one of the "z" variables, even if they are not part of the literals being resolved? If I don't rename, then the resolvent (new clause) is R(z) | Q(z). If I rename the "z" in the first sentence to "w", then the resolvent becomes R(w) | Q(z). Is it OK for the resolvent (new clause) to have a new variable (in this case, "w") that is not present in the existing KB? Thanks.

author: Vinod Sharma
Vibhu Tiwari (anon. to classmates)
student_answer.text: Yes its alright to have a new variable added in KB. Infact before resolving we first do Standardization which is to rename all the variables, so that there is no confusion and each clause has a different one.

title: Vocareum submission for Java and C++ using Makefile
author: Vinod Sharma
text:
To allow arbitrary choice of parsing libraries (supported by Vocareum), submission script will now accept a "Makefile".

If your submission contains a "Makefile", then it must support "run" target so that command "make run" compiles and runs the homework program.

If "Makefile" is not present, then submission script will try to compile and run the program assuming you are not using any external library for parsing.

The following is the content of an example Makefile for Java when using ANTLR for parsing.

#####Makefile Starts#####
run:
        javac -cp .:/home/local/voctools/Java/antlr-4.5.3-complete.jar homework*.java && java -cp .:/home/local/voctools/Java/antlr-4.5.3-complete.jar homework

clean:
        rm *.class output.txt
#####Makefile Ends#####

Note: above Makefile assumes that you have already generated the Java parsing code using ANTLR grammar file and is submitted along with your submission.
  #pin

What should be the result for unifying the following two sentences:
A(Bob, Bob)
~A(z, x) | ~A(x, y) | A(z, y)

author: Keerthan Harish Vasist
Shreyas Singapura

It should be ~A(Bob, y) | A(Bob, y) or TRUE? 
Edit
I think this will produce A(Bob,Bob). But KB already has it. So, nothing happens. As good as no unification.This makes sense because 2 is actually 
(A(z, x) & A(x, y)) => A(z, y) which is transitive property. So,

title: Clarification about Resolution
author: Sami Ullah Kashif
text:
I have 3 questions that I need clarification for:
  Question 1:
  Let us say that after performing resolution many times, I get the following two clauses:
  Clause 1: ~F(x) //here x is a variable
Clause 2: F(Bob) //Bob is constant
  Now when I will resolve the above 2 clauses, I will get the empty set, right? We don't explicitly need F(Bob) and ~F(Bob) to get the contradiction?
  Question 2:
  Contradiction can only be achieved if I am resolving 2 clauses each having 1 predicate in them. If I have more than 1 predicate in either of the clauses, I can't get contradiction? Basically I am trying to find necessary and sufficient conditions to get a contradiction?
  Question 3:
  If we resolve F(x) and ~F(y) [where x and y are variables], we don't get a contradiction. Is this right?
  Thanks in advance.

author: Chai Zheng Xin
student_answer.text:
1: yes
2. Yes. However, note that clauses with multiple predicates might be factored to a single predicate clause which then can reach contradiction by resolving with another clause. 
E.g. P(x) | P(y) can be factored to be P(y) with MGU {x/y}
3: I think that is still a contradiction but you can assume KB will not have such a form since it is guaranteed to be consistent.

followup.name: Sriram (anon. to classmates)
followup.text:
Can you elaborate more on the answer you gave for question 2? The resolution won't return the contradiction. 
  1. P(x) | P(y)
2. ~P(A)
3. 1+2 will give P(y)
4. 1+2 will give P(x) 
5. you may further resolve 2 and 3 to get a contradiction (they are single predicate clauses)
  //you do the resolution predicate wise. Isn't that what the resolution rule says?

replies.name: Chai Zheng Xin
replies.text: You are right. I was implying that 1 is not a single predicate clause but its existence would still allow a contradiction later on with 2.

replies.name: Sriram (anon. to classmates)
replies.text: Cool! You may wanna update the answer so others don't get confused.

title: HW3 TimeLimit
author: Han Zhao (anon. to classmates)
text: Where can I find time limit for HW3 for any languages?

followup.name: Haipeng Guan (anon. to classmates)
followup.text: Is this the time limit for a single query in a test case, or the limit for a whole test case (which might consist of several queries)?

replies.name: Vinod Sharma
replies.text: It's the time limit for a single query in a test case.

followup.name: Kaushalkumar (anon. to classmates)
followup.text: If there are 10 queries in the example, would our code be automatically terminated in 300 seconds ?

replies.name: Vinod Sharma
replies.text:
The program will be terminated automatically if it consumes more time than allowed. In 10 query case, we allow it to run for slightly more than 300 seconds (For example 350 seconds). Additional time is needed to account for other parts of the homework: for example reading KB and converting it to CNF.

It's best if you spend no more than 30 seconds on each query so that we don't have to terminate the program.

replies.name: Steven Ly
replies.text: My code is taking a while to check for loops in the false case for test case 1 (Ancestor(Liz,Billy), around 40 or so seconds. It's executing pretty fast for true cases, and very fast for example 1. Is this 30 second policy concrete? I'm using java for my code fyi.

replies.name: Vinod Sharma
replies.text: If a code is taking around 40 seconds to run a query, you do not need to worry about it, we will allow a program to run for more than this time. 30 seconds time limit is to stop the badly implemented program from running for a long time.

title: Resolving complimentary symbols
author: Sami Ullah Kashif
text:
I am having trouble resolving the last rule in Example 2 of the assignment. The rule after converting to CNF becomes:
  ~Parent(x,y) | ~Ancestor(y,z) | Ancestor(x,z)
  Shouldn't we resolve the last two predicates to get TRUE? Basically my question is that can we simplify the above rule or not?

author: Chai Zheng Xin
student_answer.text:
I don't think you can drop the rule. There are models where the statement is not a tautology, e.g. ~Parent(Mary,John) | ~Ancestor(John,Bob) | Ancestor(Mary,Bob).
  The only time you can drop is if 2 predicates have exactly the same terms and are negation of each other, e.g. ~Ancestor(y,z) | Ancestor(y,z).

title: Clarification about example1
author: Kalhan Koul
text:
Dear TA's,
  Clauses
F(x)=>G(x)
H(x)=>F(x)
  resolve to G(x) | ~H(x)              -(1)
  and there is another clause in KB G(x)=>H(x)    -(2)
since 1 & 2 resolve to {}, every query would return true.
  But clearly this doesn't match the sample outputs.
What I am trying to suggest is that loops are leading to inconsistent KB.
Am I wrong in my interpretation. 
Thanks!

author: Timothy Wade (anon. to classmates)
student_answer.text:
I don't blame you for the confusion, I had a bit at first too.
  (G(x) | ~H(x)) and (~G(x) | H(x)) don't cancel each other out.  If you resolve them, your result will be two statements: 1) G(x) | ~G(x) 2) H(x) | ~H(x).  Obviously those statements are consistent (if not especially helpful).  The issue you're running into is that you're attempting to eliminate two terms as a result of resolution, but resolution is only performed on a single term at a time.

followup.name: Hannes Leipold (anon. to classmates)
followup.text: In the answer given, why wouldn't G(x) | ~G(x) simplify to True? And I would this means that G(x) | ~G(x) and H(x) | ~H(x) are removed from our KB.

replies.name: Timothy Wade (anon. to classmates)
replies.text:
G(x) | ~G(x) does simplify to True.  It indicates that the conjunction that derived is always true which makes it unfruitful for a proof by contradiction.  
  It could probably be removed from the KB given that it may lead to fruitless resolution (with itself, among others).

title: What is "factoring" in resolution
author: HAO WU (anon. to classmates)
text:
Can someone explain what is "factoring" in resolution?  It will be best to give some examples.
Thanks!

author: Om Patri
Jichao Zhong (anon. to classmates)
student_answer.text:
In propositional logic
The removal of multiple copies of literals is called factoring. 
For example, if we resolve (A ∨ B) with (A ∨ ¬B), we obtain (A ∨ A), which is reduced to just A.
  The thing is similar in FOL.

followup.name: YUANKUN XUE
followup.text:
Let us say we have two sentences: P(John, w) | P(John, z)   resolved with ((~P(x,y)) | K(x,y)), which yields two new sentences:
K(John, z) | P(John, w)
and
K(John, w) | P(John,z)
They are equivalent whereas the names of the variable are exchanged. We need to do factoring for this case ? Or we have to eliminate the input like P(John, z) | P(John, w) first ?

replies.name: Jichao Zhong (anon. to classmates)
replies.text:
I think these two new sentences won't show at the same time.
Each time you choose one unification {x/John, w/y} to yield  K(John, z) | P(John, w)
or another unification {x/John, z/y} to yield K(John, w) | P(John,z)
  then unify with ((~P(x,y)) | K(x,y)) again
 K(John, z) | P(John, w) --  ((~P(x,y)) | K(x,y)) --{x/John, w/y}---> K(John, z) | K(John, y)
or
K(John, w) | P(John,z) -- ((~P(x,y)) | K(x,y)) --{x/John, z/y}---> K(John, z) | K(John, y)
  The order dose not matter.
The point is that only one unification can be choosen for each unifying action.

followup.name: YUANKUN XUE
followup.text:
Moreover, how do we process KB sentence that resolves with themselves ? e.g, (P(John, x) | ~P(x, y) | ....)
  Is there any constraint on the KB input for this case ?

replies.name: Vinod Sharma
replies.text: Resolution always occurs between two sentences.

followup.name: Shreyas Singapura
followup.text: Is factoring necessary for correctness? Or is it used to speed up the process?

replies.name: Jichao Zhong (anon. to classmates)
replies.text:
The binary resolution rule by itself does not yield a complete inference procedure.
The combination of binary resolution and factoring is complete. (Page 347, AIMA 3rd edition)

replies.name: Shreyas Singapura
replies.text: can you give an example where factoring makes it complete and without factoring is incomplete?

title: Unclear HW3 Hint: Binding Constants During Proving Process
author: Zachariah Hayes
text:
How should we interpret the following HW3 hint?
  If you decide that the given statement can be inferred from the knowledgebase, every variable in each sentence used in the proving process should be unified with a Constant. So, if you have something like A(x) => B(John), and you cannot find any x to fulfill the A(x) premise, you cannot say that B(John) is true.
  Does this mean that given the following KB:
  ~A(x) | B(y)
A(z)
  we cannot infer B(y) without constants to bind to each variable during the single possible resolution step?
    What is the purpose of this hint?  Is it to restrict the search space?

followup.name: Hannes Leipold (anon. to classmates)
followup.text:
My understanding would be that our kb having A(y) in it, means that for all y, A(y) is true. Then when you resolve this with other entries in the KB, any clause that has ~A(y) (or any other free variable in the place of y) would have this part of the disjunction resolved. 
  So my feeling would be that ~A(x) | B(y) and A(z) SHOULD resolve to B(y) without any constant bindings.
(I answer as a follow up as not to deter the instructors from giving an official response, which this question deserves).

title: Understanding Unify Pseudo-code in AIAMA
author: Mark Debord (anon. to classmates)
text:
Hi all. My code seems to only work on very simple examples and I've found my problem is unification. I believe my attempt at unification is over-simplified and I end up not unifying things that should. I've gone back to the pseudo-code in AIAMA (posted below) but I don't quite understand what some of the statements mean.
  The way I have it implemented the second recursive Unify call "Unify(Rest[x], Rest[y], Unify(First[x],First[y],Theta) )" causes me to fail too early (I think). 
  Say x = (A(v1,v2) | B(v2,Bob) ) and y = (B(Jack,v3) | (~A(v4,v5)))
  This should unify {v1/v4, v2/Jack, v3/Bob, v5/Jack} which would lead to resolution (B(Jack, Bob) | B(Jack, Bob)) which factors to B(Jack, Bob) correct?
  If I follow the pseudo code, On the first entry of unify:
 x,y are both lists, The First[x] is A(v1,v2), First[y] is B(Jack,v3). 
I use this in the Unify statement for if x and y are both lists
So now when computing Unify for x = A(v1,v2), y = B(Jack,v3)
Both x and y are compounds, Op[x] = A Op[y] = B
So go to Unify statement where x = A, y = B
Both x and y are function symbols and they are not equivalent so I go to "else return failure"
This cascades up and the whole thing fails here.
  I also seem to fail on sentences that have different number of predicates. In fact the only time it seems to work is if both sentences have the same number of predicates, the predicates all have the same names, and they are all ordered in the same way. I'm clearly misreading the pseudo code, I'm guessing I'm misunderstanding what is meant by "Compound?" "List?" and how "First" and "Rest" are supposed to work.
  Sorry if this doesn't make any sense. I'll try to explain more if necessary
        I've tried implementing my own version of unification with a dfs-like search but that hasn't gone well either :/. The only other thing I can think of to try is brute force which seems unnecessary

author: Shreyas Singapura
student_answer.text:
Say x = (A(v1,v2) | B(v2,Bob) ) and y = (B(Jack,v3) | (~A(v4,v5)))
  This should unify {v1/v4, v2/v5} because A and ~A, which would lead to resolution (B(v5, Bob) | B(Jack, v3))
I do not know how you arrived at your solution. Can you explain?

followup.name: Mark Debord (anon. to classmates)
followup.text:
You are correct that does seem like the most general unifier. But the pseudo-code in the book does not work in this scenario.
    On the first entry of Unify(x = (A(v1,v2) | B(v2,Bob) ) , y = (B(Jack,v3) | (~A(v4,v5))), Theta = {}) It looks like we call the 'If both lists' statement 
 Unify(x = B(v2,Bob), y = (~A(v4,v5)), Theta = Unify(A(v1,v2),B(Jack,v3), {}))
The inner Unify(x = A(v1,v2), y = B(Jack,v3), Theta = {}) now calls 'If both compound' statement
Unify(x = (v1,v2), y = (Jack,v3), Theta = Unify(A,B,{}))
The inner unify goes to 'Else return failure' because A != B and we work our way back up
Unify(x = (v1,v2), y = (Jack,v3), Theta = Failure) since Theta = Failure, this also returns failure
 Unify(x = B(v2,Bob), y = (~A(v4,v5)), Theta = Failure) since Theta = Failure, this now returns failure
Unify(x = B(v2,Bob), y = (~A(v4,v5)), Theta = Failure), again returns failure
The whole thing has failed.
  So, since x,y have their predicates ordered differently the whole things fails. If I try again with them ordered in the same way x = (A(v1,v2) | B(v2,Bob) ), y = ((~A(v4,v5)) | B (Jack,v3)) now it will work and it will return the solution I originally posted
  On the first entry of Unify(x = (A(v1,v2) | B(v2,Bob) ) , y = ((~A(v4,v5)) | B(Jack,v3)), Theta = {}) It looks like we call the 'If both lists' statement 
 Unify(x = (A(v1,v2)), y =(~A(v4,v5))), Theta = Unify(B(v2,Bob),B(Jack,v3), {}))
The inner Unify(x = B(v2,Bob), y = B(Jack,v3), Theta = {}) now calls 'If both compound' statement
Unify(x = (v2,Bob), y = (Jack,v3), Theta = Unify(B,B,{}))
The inner unify goes to x = y= B return {}
Unify(x = (v2,Bob), y = (Jack,v3), Theta = {}) now calls 'If both Lists'
Unify(x = Bob, y = v3, Theta = Unify(v2,Jack, {})) the inner unify has x = variable, y = constant, so we can call Unify-Var
Unify-Var(var = v2, x = Jack, Theta = {}), neither are in theta already so now we add  {v2/Jack} to theta
Unify(x = Bob, y = v3, Theta = {v2/Jack}) y is variable so we call Unify-var
Unify-Var(var = v3, x = Bob, Theta = {v2/Jack}), neither are in theta so we add  {v3/Bob} to theta
Now if both lists returns {v2/Jack,v3/Bob}
Now the previous 'If both compound statement can return Theta = {v2/Jack,v3/Bob}
Now we co back to 'If both lists' with new Theta
Unify(x = (A(v1,v2)), y =(~A(v4,v5))), Theta = {v2/Jack,v3/Bob}), now calls 'If both compound statement'
Unify(x = (v1,v2), y = (v4,v5), Theta = Unify(A,A,{v2/Jack,v3/Bob}))
Inner unify has x = y = A, so we just return {v2/Jack,v3/Bob}
Unify(x = (v1,v2), y = (v4,v5), Theta = {v2/Jack,v3/Bob}) now calls 'If both lists' again
Unify(x = v2, y = v5, Theta = Unify(v1,v4, {v2/Jack,v3/Bob})) the inner unify are both variables so we call Unify-Var
Unify-Var(var = v1, x = v4, {v2/Jack,v3/Bob}), neither v1 or v4 are in the list so we add {v1/v4} to theta
Unify(x = v2, y = v5, Theta = {v2/Jack,v3/Bob, v1/v4}) both x and y are vars we we call Unify-Var
Unify-Var(var = v2, x = v5, Theta = {v2/Jack,v3/Bob, v1/v4}), but v2 is already in Theta with val = Jack, so we use the if statement
Unify(Jack, v5, Theta = {v2/Jack,v3/Bob, v1/v4}), y is avariable so we call Unify-Var
Unify-Var(v5,Jack, Theta = {v2/Jack,v3/Bob, v1/v4}), v5 is not already in so we add {v5,Jack} to theta
now return Theta = {v2/Jack,v3/Bob, v1/v4, v5/Jack}
return Theta = {v2/Jack,v3/Bob, v1/v4, v5/Jack}
return Theta = {v2/Jack,v3/Bob, v1/v4, v5/Jack}
return Theta = {v2/Jack,v3/Bob, v1/v4, v5/Jack}
return Theta = {v2/Jack,v3/Bob, v1/v4, v5/Jack}
return Theta = {v2/Jack,v3/Bob, v1/v4, v5/Jack}
  And that is how I got my answer. I just followed the book's pseudo code. But as I showed it doesn't seem to work if the ordering of the predicates are different. It also fails if there are a different number of predicates, or if some of the predicates don't have matching names. Both of those scenarios occur very often so it doesn't seem like the book's pseudo-code works with them. I've spent a bunch of time trying to force it to work by re-ordering predicates (which helps some) and trying to only match parts of the sentences with the same predicates (which is faulty, because it removes conflicts that might be important), but I still can't seem to do it.

title: Question about max bounds for predicates, queries, and sentences
author: Dennis Evans
text:
I am having difficulty deciding how much space I need to allocate to pass the test cases.
The homework specifies:
• Each predicate takes at least one argument. Predicates will take at most 100 arguments.
• There will be at most 100 queries and 1000 sentences in the knowledge base.
  Are these bounds for the text file or during execution of the algorithm?  If they are only for the text file, it really does not tell us anything about the amount of space we must allocate.

Could we also have a bounds for the max # of predicates a sentence can contain?  Without this, the # of clauses in the KB could potentially be infinite after converting to CNF.  Imagine 1000 sentences with 1000 predicates, all & together.
To handle this the KB would have to be able to hold 1000^2 clauses.
Even without such an extreme example, if you have 1000 sentences on the input file the KB could easily grow to an unpredictable factor.

title: About Knowledge Base...
author: Xuechao (anon. to classmates)
text:
Before we negate the query and start resolution, do we need to process KB to generate inferred clauses ?
In the case below, before resolving negated query, KB started "self-resolution" and stopped at "Rich (me)" which contradicts the negated query.
  For more complex cases, if we have to let KB do "self-resolution", the size of KB could be rather large. How do we decide when to quit "KB self-resolving" and start resolving with the negated query?

author: Hannes Leipold
student_answer.text:
I think no, because you don't necessarily know at what depth in the resolution your query will be used to simplify to the contradiction. In this proof, we never needed the instance (Me), except for at the very end. I think in more complicated cases, this might not hold. Instead, I think you add the negated query and just begin running the resolution algorithm ad nauseum. 
  Source:
http://slidewiki.org/slide/15480

title: Opposite terms in a clause
author: Hannes Leipold (anon. to classmates)
text:
Suppose we have two clauses:
1. ( ( A(x) | B(y) ) | C(z) )
2. ( (~A(x) ) | (~B(y) ) )
  On resolution, we may get the clause:
( ( B(y) | ~B(y) ) | C(z) )
  Which simplifies to Truth right? So then our query is true right?

author: Muye Zhu (anon. to classmates)
student_answer.text: B(y)|~B(y) is tautology, so ( ( B(y) | ~B(y) ) | C(z) ) is always true. I think in this case the clause shouldn't be added to KB, since C(z) can not be inferred.

followup.name: Hannes Leipold (anon. to classmates)
followup.text: Something that is always true OR something that might be true is always true though.

title: What is the output of following two cases?
author: Jincheng He (anon. to classmates)
text:
case 1:
1
A(P)

  case 2:
1

P(x)|Q(y)|Q(x)
~Q(A)|~Q(z)
  In my opinion, according to Hint 1, both should return FALSE, I wonder whether I am right or not.

author: YUANKUN XUE
student_answer.text:
I do not think it will return FALSE for the second case.
For case 2,  you first do factoring the P(x) | Q(y) | Q(x), resuling in P(x) | Q(x). Then to ~Q(A) | ~Q(z), you get ~Q(A), thus the new KB contains:
P(x) | Q(x)
~Q(A)
Then you add ~P(A) to the KB, the resolution follows: 
P(x) | Q(x) resolves with ~P(A) -> Q(A) contradicts with ~Q(A), hence the query is entailed. 
  Please correct me if I am wrong.

followup.name: Shreyas Singapura
followup.text: The first question is similar to one of the my posts: @775

followup.name: Hannes Leipold
followup.text: I would think the first one should be true, since for all x, A(x) is true in our universe, so clearly A(P) for some P should be true. Clearly {x->P} gives us ~A(P) and A(P), which is a contradiction, so there is a simple resolution proof.

title: Different answer between Vocareum and local Machine
author: Martha Monica (anon. to classmates)
text:
I am using c++, and really confuse because my answer in Vocareum different with what I get in my machine.
Any idea what causing that?

followup.name: Giridhar Akila Dhakshinamoorthy
followup.text:
Check for default keywords in your program. The local ide over sees them. Whereas in vocareum if you have used a default keyword as a function.name or a variable name, be fareful. Examples may be like "literals" or "index" or something like that.
  And be careful while performing pointer operations. In thr local.machine the ptr memory management is much simpler than it is in vocareum. As much as possible I would suggest you to referain from using ptrs or argument calls by reference.

author: Nguyen (Chris) Tran (anon. to classmates)
text:
I have difficult time calculating the probabilities given in this example which can be found in Mon-Wed lecture session 22 slide 66-71
  On slide 68, there are 3 probabilities:
  P(l1) = .502
P(l1 | i0) = .389
P(l1 | i0, d0) = .513
  In my understanding, P(l1 | i0, d0) = P(l1 | g1)*P(g1 | i0, d0) + P(l1 | g2)*P(g2 | i0,d0) + P(l1 | g3)*P(g3| i0,d0). With this formula, I'm able to get .513
  However, when I try to calculate P(l1 | i0), I have the following:
P(l1 | i0) = P(l1 | g1)*P(g1 | i0) + P(l1 | g2)*P(g2 | i0) + P(l1 | g3)*P(g3 | i0)
  To calculate P(g1 | i0), I think it is P(g1 | i0) = P(g1 | i0, d0)*P(i0)*P(d0) + P(g1 | i0, d1)*P(i0)*P(d1), Is this correct? I follow this formula to calculate P(g2 | i0) and P(g3 | i0) and plug them in the original formula, but could not get the expected result of .389
  Is there something I am missing? Greatly appreciated for some guidance
    Thank you in advance

author: ANUSHA BILAKANTI (anon. to classmates)
student_answer.text: How is P(l1) = .502 calculated?

followup.name: Nguyen (Chris) Tran (anon. to classmates)
followup.text: Could one of TA please help?

followup.name: Nguyen (Chris) Tran (anon. to classmates)
followup.text:
Thanks @Thomas Collins  . 
  Now I understand it better, but am still confused at 1 spot. For example, we have node m which has b and d as its parents, then
  P(m | b) = P(m | b,d) * P(d | b) + P(m | b, ~d) * P(~d | b). Is it correct? If so, I quite don't understand how we come up with this expansion, especially the part with P (d | b) and P(~d | b)
  Thanks

replies.name: Thomas Collins
replies.text:
P(m|b)=
Σ
d
P(m,d|b)=
Σ
d
P(m|b,d)P(d|b)=P(m|b,d)P(d|b)+P(m|b, d)P( d|b)
. I believe that is the same as what you wrote. I hope the way I derived it makes it a little clearer what the intermediate steps are.

replies.name: Nguyen (Chris) Tran (anon. to classmates)
replies.text:
The part I don't understand is this: ΣdP(m,d|b)=ΣdP(m|b,d)P(d|b).
  How do we do the transition from P(m,d |b) to P(m, | d,b)*P(d|b). What rule are we using here?

replies.name: Thomas Collins
replies.text: I am not sure the rule has a specific name other than the multiplication rule of probability, with the addition of evidence (b in this case). Note that B stays behind the conditioning bar at every step. The multiplication rule of probability is P(A, B) = P(A)P(B|A) = P(B)P(A|B). With evidence c, this becomes P(A, B | c) = P(A | B, c)P(B | c) = P(B | A, c)P(A | c). The summation over d is just to marginalize out the variable D. what is left, after the application of these rules is: P(m | b)

title: MT2 problem 1 part i
author: Bi Wang (anon. to classmates)
text:
“Everything is attracted by something”, where “something” means “something or other”, is equivalent to “ Exist x, All y, Attract(x, y) ” 
  Why this is true? 
Exist x, All y should not be equal to All y, Exist x

author: Abijith Sankar Kottappurath Narayanan (anon. to classmates)
student_answer.text: I too have the same doubt

followup.name: Anushree Kaipa Ramanath (anon. to classmates)

replies.name: Anushree Kaipa Ramanath (anon. to classmates)
replies.text: Doesn't "Exist x, All y" this mean - There is something that attracts everything?

replies.name: Hannes Leipold
replies.text:
Exists x, all y means there exists a particular x, say x1, for which all y is attracted by x1. Then Attracts(x1,_) maps to all of y. 
  However, "for all y, there exists x" means that all of y is attracted by some collection {x1, x2, ..., xn} so that all of y is mapped to, but it might be different x's for each y that accomplish this. So "there exists x, for all y" implies "for all y, there exists x", but not vice versa.

replies.name: Anushree Kaipa Ramanath (anon. to classmates)
replies.text:
I do not think understand this implication :-
"there exists x, for all y" implies "for all y, there exists x"

replies.name: Anushree Kaipa Ramanath (anon. to classmates)
replies.text:
A very similar example has been discussed in class. Slide 21 from session 11-12 presentation, according to which the given statement should be False from what I understand.
  Can some TA or professor please clarify?
  I am not asking this for extra marks. But I would like to clear my doubt so that I don't make the mistake again.

replies.name: Hannes Leipold
replies.text:
If the statement 
∃x,∀yAttracts(x.y)
is true, then in particular there is some x1 for which
∀y,Attracts(x1,y)
is true. Then in particular
∀y,∃x,Attracts(x,y)
is true, because we have x1. So we have a collection {x1} so that for each y, an item in the collection makes the statement true. Clearly not vice versa, because all we know from
∀y,∃xAttracts(x,y)
is that there is some collection {x1, x2, ..., xn}, but we don't know the cardinality of the set.

title: Filtering example
author: Suxin Li
ANUSHA BILAKANTI
text:
Session 25
Slide 35
  Can anyone explain how the value of α is obtained under Day 1 and Day 2?
Day 0:
  P(R0)=<0.5,0.5>
Day 1 (Umbrella appears è U1=true)
  P(R1)=P(r0)P(R1|r0)
    = α0.5<0.7,0.3> + α0.5<0.3,0.7>
    = <0.5,0.5>
  updating with evidence for t=1 gives:
  P(R1|u1)=αP(u1|R1)P(R1)=α<0.9,0.2><0.5,0.5>
       =α<0.45,0.1> = <0.818,0.182>
Day 2 (Umbrella appears è U2=true)
  P(R2|u1)=P(R2|r1) P(r1|u1)
              =α<0.818<0.7,0.3> + 0.182<0.3,0.7>> = <0.627,0.373>
  updating with evidence for t=2 gives:
  P(R2|u1,u2)=αP(u2|R2)P(R2|u1)=α<0.9,0.2><0.627,0.373>
          =α<0.565,0.075> = <0.883,0.117>

author: Suxin Li
student_answer.text: In my opinion, because you use Enumeration, the sum of conditional probabilities of all cases is 1. I think alpha is a kind of trick that you can avoid  calculate those probabilities repeatedly. For instance. you need to calculate P(A | b). P(A | b) = P(A b) / P(b) = alpha * P(A  b). P(A  b) = <P(a b), P( ~a b)>  and alpha = 1/P(b). You can calculate alpha by alpha = 1 / (P(a b ) + P(~a b) ). But you have already attained<P(a b), P( ~a b)>, you can just sum them up to get alpha rather than starting from scratch, which might take long time.

title: Can someone explain the last step?
author: Kaushal Shah (anon. to classmates)
text:
P(x|E) = p(xE)/P(E) = P(xOA)/P(OA)
  = p(x|A)p(O|xA)/p(O|A)
I do understand that E=OA but i am unclear on the last step.
Can someone please explain in detailed steps?

author: Bojun Huang
Chai Zheng Xin
student_answer.text:
P(xOA) = P(xO|A)P(A)
             = P(x|A)P(O|xA)P(A)
P(OA) = P(O|A)P(A)
Therefore, P(xOA)/P(OA) = P(x|A)P(O|xA) / P(O|A) because the P(A) cancels out.

replies.name: Mark Debord (anon. to classmates)
replies.text:
P(xOA) = P(x|OA)P(OA) is also a valid way to start to resolve this.
  The end goal is to get to probabilities that are more easily calculated (or given) by the model. In the little prince example we want to be able to directly use the probabilities given in the tables in slide 3 session. p(x|A) is simply a product series of values from the transition probability tables, and p(O|xA) is a product series from the appearance probabilities. We like these terms because those are probabilities that are more easily measured. The only difficult term in the expression is P(O|A), which is calculable as a dynamic program (forward and backwards procedures)
    If you wanted to start to shape the P(xOA)/P(OA) expression to use p(x|A) and p(O|xA) you could do it like this:
  P(xOA)/P(OA) = P(x|OA)P(OA)/P(OA), simplifying fraction you are left with P(x|OA)
  P(x|OA) = 
      P(OA|x)P(x)      P(O|xA)*P(A|x)*P(x)         P(O|xA)*(P(x|A)P(A)/P(x))*P(x)         P(x|A)P(O|xA)
     --------------  =   ------------------------   =   ---------------------------------------- =    --------------------  <--- this is the expression we were trying to get to
         P(OA)                 P(O|A)P(A)                                P(O|A)P(A)                             P(O|A)

title: How to calculate the denominator?
author: Anshuli Patil (anon. to classmates)
text:
P(i1 \ g3,s1) = P(i1, g3, s1)/P(g3,s1)
  Now I am getting the numerator by summing out the variables. 
How do I calculate the denominator?
    Slide 70 from session 22 MondayWednesday class. Can't paste here for some odd reason.
Many thanks

author: Kaushal Shah (anon. to classmates)
Anshuli Patil
student_answer.text:
It can be done in a similar way to the numerator, by summing out over the other three variables. In fact, P(g3,s1) = P(i1, g3, s1) + P(i0, g3, s1)
Also, P(i1, g3, s1) = P(i1, g3, s1, d0) + P(i1, g3, s1, d1)
                             = P(i1) * P(s1| i1) * ( P(g3 | d0, i1  *  P(d0) +  P(g3 | d1, i1  *  P(d1) )
  See @801 and @797

replies.name: Duc Ho
replies.text:
It should be 0.502. The way I usually do it is i go from the parent down to the one variable in consideration. So first you have no observation/assumptions that is given. You have to substitute 2 values for D0(0.6) and D1(0.4) and multiply accordingly to the table below ( Grade table ). For example : now P(I0,G1) = P(D0)*P(I0,D0,G1) + P(D1)*P(I0,D1,G1) = 0.6 * 0.3 + 0.4*0.05 = 0.2. Now that D is gone, you do the same for I. ,e.g : P(G1) = P(I0)*P(I0,G1) + P(I1)*P(I1,G1) = 0.7*0.2 + 0.3*0.74 = 0.362. Now that I is gone you end up with the last table, do the same.P(L1) = P(G1)*P(G1,L1) + P(G2)*P(G2,L1) + P(G3)*P(G3,L1) = 0.9 * 0.362 + 0.6*0.2884 + 0.01*0.3496 = 0.50234 . (P(G2) , P(G3) is calculated on previous step ).
When you are given(observation is made) like in 2). P(L1| I0). You could cut the row having I1 when calculating P(D0,G1) and P(D1,G1) . Speaking of I1, the table is likely wrong ( Do you see any I1 anywhere, the last two row of Grade table is of I1 variable). Professor please verify slides when you adapt it. Well, i traced it down and it seems that it comes from one university to another to ... a chapter in a book which the table is wrong too. Cant blame ya, the source is wrong.

title: Finding number of entries in CPT
author: Sneha Salvi (anon. to classmates)
text:
Hi,
  For the question below, According to me the total number of entries would be 10 (A =2, B=2, C=2, D=4). Is this answer correct?

author: Chirag Sanghvi (anon. to classmates)
student_answer.text:
The answer is 16 as you need to consider the complement of B and D entries too.
  A = 2
B = 2
C = P(C|A) = 4
D = P(D|A,B) = 8
  Total: 16

followup.name: Sneha Salvi (anon. to classmates)
followup.text:
I think its fine if we don't consider the complement.
  eg: for C we can have only two entries as below:
  A  C
T  0.9
F  0.2
  If we know that P(C|A)=0.9 than P(~C|A) would be 0.1 We don't have to specify it.

followup.name: ANUSHA BILAKANTI (anon. to classmates)
followup.text:
Isn't it just 10 entries?
  2 each for A,B and C. 4 for D.
    How is it this?
  C = P(C|A) = 4
D = P(D|A,B) = 8

followup.name: ANUSHA BILAKANTI (anon. to classmates)
followup.text: How is it that P(C|A) has 4 entries,a nd P(D|A,B) has 8 entries?

replies.name: Thomas Collins
replies.text:
P(C|A) has 4 total values, P(c | a), P(c | -a), P(-c|a), and P(-c|-a). Similarly, P(D|A,B) has 8 values in the CPT. However, only 2 values (P(c|a) and P(c|-a)) are independent. This is what I mean by parameters. P(-c|a) and P(-c|-a) can be determined via the sum to one constraint once P(c|a) and P(c|-a) are set. Similarly, P(D|A,B) requires only 4 independent parameters (P(d|a,b), P(d | a, -b), P(d | -a, b), P(d | -a, -b)), because the others can be recovered via sum to one constraints. I hope this helps.

As I said above and below, I think the question is vague. I believe it is asking for independent parameters, which is the minimum number of independent values required to fully specify a CPT. When I see the term "entries", I take that to mean the total number of values in the CPT (some of which are related by normalization constraints).

followup.name: Sneha Salvi (anon. to classmates)
followup.text:
@Thomas Collins  Thank you for the explanation. However, the question is asking what is the minimum number of probability entries needed for A, B, C and D. SO wouldn't the answer be 16 rather than 7?
  Also when you say 16 I am still confused why can't C have just 2 entries instead of 4. As we can calculate the false value by taking (1-true) value.

replies.name: Thomas Collins
replies.text:
I said in my post above that I don't believe that question is asking for CPT entries, as it makes the question rather trivial. The joint distribution has 2^4 = 16 entries, 15 of which are independent of one another (due to the sum to one constraint).

However, in the first part of the answer, I did say that you could parameterize P(C|A) with 2 parameters, even though there are four entries in the CPT. In my opinion, the term "entries" is not a good way to describe what is being asked, and I think the question is thus a little vague. So, to answer your question: yes, you only need to values to fully specify P(C|A), but there are four total values in P(C|A) (with two sum to one constraints)

The reason I think the question is asking for independent parameters is because it is asking for the "minimum" number of entries. This part of the question doesn't make sense to me unless it is talking about independent parameters

replies.name: Thomas Collins
replies.text: The answer is 8. If I wrote 7 somewhere, I apologize. The answer should be 8 parameters.

replies.text: It seems that I wrote 8 and 7 above. But if you follow my example of how to calculate the parameters , you will get 8

replies.name: Hannes Leipold
replies.text: E causes C so C happening is correlated with E, but F happening is not correlated with E. The thing is, F happening might cause C to happen, and C happening is correlated with E, but this does not mean F is correlated with E, because, for example, your basket might not be empty because you have an apple or an orange in it, but knowing you have an orange in your basket does not tell you if your basket has an apple. At least this how I understand it, but look at D-separation and independence in Bayesian Networks to understand it better.

title: Q1.2
author: Chun-Ning Chang (anon. to classmates)
text:
Probability theory and propositional logic make the same epistemological commitments.
Can someone please explain what does the sentence means and why it is false?
Thank you very much!

author: Bojun Huang
Mugzar Akizhanov (anon. to classmates)
student_answer.text:
from AIMA p.482 : "In the terminology of Section 8.1, the ontological commitments of logic and probability theory are the same—that the world is
composed of facts that do or do not hold in any particular case—but the epistemological commitments are different: a logical agent believes each sentence to be true or false or has no opinion, whereas a probabilistic agent may have a numerical degree of belief between 0 (for sentences that are certainly false) and 1 (certainly true)".

author: Jichao Zhong (anon. to classmates)
student_answer.text:
for C,F, when S is unkonwn, C & F are conditionally independent, called head-to-head conditionally independent.
P(C,F)=
∑
s
P(C,F,S)=
∑
s
P(C)P(F)P(S|C,F)=P(C)P(F)
  however, when S is known, the situation changes. we have to use Bayes' rule, this is what question (6) asked.

when you sum for E = +e, -e, 
∑P(s|c,f)P(c|E)P(E)P(f) = P(s|c,f)P(c|e)P(e)P(f)+P(s|c,f)P(c|-e)P(-e)P(f)=P(s|c,f)P(f)(P(c|e)P(e)+P(c|-e)P(-e))=P(s|c,f)P(f)P(c)
since we have calculated P(c), it is unnecessary to do it again.

title: Decision Tree problem
author: Nguyen (Chris) Tran (anon. to classmates)
text:
Hello all,
  I am going through the decision tree problem given in lecture Mon-Wed session 19 slides 20-21, and I have some questions about classification.
  I constructed a simplified version of it for example below.
  How do we classify if we will wait or not. In other words, how do we come up with the table given on slide 20?
  For instance, if I am given:
  Patron is None, Hungry is No, Reservation is Yes, are we going to wait?
  If there is any rule we should apply, please specify. Thank you in advance

author: Sriram
student_answer.text:
you will notice that every leaf of the decision tree will be a "class". For the WillWait example its "True" or "False" as classes. 
The classification goes like this. Given a 12 attribute tuple (containing all values like Patron, hungry, wait time etc..) you start at the root of the tree and choose the attribute, follow the path in the tree till the leaf, taking that particular attribute and the value.
  For the example you have given, you come to Patron=None, you take the child of the patron that has None in the edge and you reach "true". that's it. you have classified the data. you don't need to consider any other attribute.

title: Bayes Net Question of Sample Final Paper
author: Chai Zheng Xin
text: Why is P(+c|+f) = P(+c)? F is in C's markov blanket because F is a parent of 1 of C's child. This means C and F are not conditionally independent.

followup.name: Chai Zheng Xin
followup.text: It is in question 5 page 6 of SampleFinalProblems.pdf.

replies.name: Thomas Collins
replies.text: The fact that F is in C's markov blanket does not mean that they are not independent. Recall that if we have a structure with two parents of a common child, e.g., A -> B <- C, where A and C are the parents and B is the child, the path of influence between A and C is blocked unless B (or one of B's descendants) is observed. We have the same structure here between C and F (with the common child being S). Since S is not observed, there is no path of influence between C and F, and they are independent. Since C and F are independent (not conditionally independent), P(C|F) = P(C). Observing F gives us no information about the probability of C. Notice that if S is observed, P(C|F,S) != P(C|S) because observing S activates a path of influence between F and C. I hope this helps.

replies.name: Chai Zheng Xin
replies.text: What does path of influence mean? Why would an absence or presence of a common node in the condition between 2 other nodes affect whether the 2 nodes are independent or not?

replies.name: Thomas Collins
replies.text:
The answer to your question has to do with the semantics of Bayes Nets. The D-separation criterion gives very precise rules for when two nodes are conditionally independent of one another given a third set of nodes. I am utilizing this criterion is my answer to you. I am not sure what rules you learned in class for this, but D-separation is the most comprehensive criterion for determining the answers to these questions. When using the D-separation criterion, you may hear the terms "active trail", "path of influence", etc. I am not sure if you discussed D-separation in class, but the criterion is not difficult to understand.
  Here is a link that may be of help: http://www.andrew.cmu.edu/user/scheines/tutor/d-sep.html#explanation. 
  Programs such as the Belief and Decision Network tool at: http://www.aispace.org/downloads.shtml have built in quizzes that you can use to determine if you understand the concepts of D-separation and conditional independence. It may be outside the scope of this course, though, as I am not sure what rules you learned in lecture.

replies.name: Chai Zheng Xin
replies.text: Thanks for the info.

title: Neural nets weights updates
author: Bi Wang (anon. to classmates)
text:
The output of the perception is 1 and if it is higher than the desired value, how would each of the weights on inputs a, b, c updated?
  The answer is: 
a stay the same
b and c decrease
  I have doubts on b and c.
  I use the formula: new_weight = old_weight + alpha * error_value * input
  For example, b_new_weight = b_old_weight + alpha * error_value * 1, alpha and error_value are greater than 0,
so b_new_weight > b_old_weight, weight on b should increase.
  Why the answer is decrease?

author: Hannes Leipold
student_answer.text: If the error is positive, that is, the result was higher than we want, we should clearly decrease (if not, we wouldn't move closer to the actual value) and if the error is negative, that is, the result was lower than we wanted, we should increase the weight (otherwise, how would we be moving closer to the right result?).

followup.text:

How do you explain that a should stay the same?

author: Connor Zarecki

title: What does it mean that logic is monotonic?
author: ANUSHA BILAKANTI (anon. to classmates)
Anushree Kaipa Ramanath (anon. to classmates)
student_answer.text:
Suppose, initially you are able to infer, say a statement A from the KB.
Now you add a new statement B to the KB (assuming it doesn't contradict with KB).
After adding B, you should still be able to infer A from KB.
  In short, adding new logic sentences to KB should not affect the inferences you were able to make from KB before addition of new sentences. This is what is meant by logic is monotonic.

title: difference between decision tree learning algorithm and ID3 algorithm
author: ANUSHA BILAKANTI (anon. to classmates)
text: What is difference between decision tree learning algorithm and ID3 algorithm?

author: Anushree Kaipa Ramanath (anon. to classmates)
student_answer.text:
Decision tree learning is the construction of a decision tree from class-labeled training tuples. A decision tree is a flow-chart-like structure, where each internal (non-leaf) node denotes a test on an attribute, each branch represents the outcome of a test, and each leaf (or terminal) node holds a class label. The topmost node in a tree is the root node.
There are many specific decision-tree algorithms. ID3 is one such

replies.name: Damien Tan Rong Tai
replies.text:
I failed this test case too. I think the resolution process should go like this:
  (Employee(x) | Employee(y))           ~Employee(Alice)
{x/Alice}
Employee(y)                                     ~Employee(Alice)
{y/Alice}
{} (Contradiction)
  Variables x and y are not necessarily unique.
So ~Employee(Alice) must be stored in the KB and retrieved again for resolution.

replies.name: Sriram

title: Exam 3 | Question 4 | Value Iteration
author: Anamika Rani Bir (anon. to classmates)
text:
As per the slides, 
    and in the exam solution we have,
      Shouldn't it be    
50   100   0
25    50   100

author: Sriram
student_answer.text: The r(s, a) =1 for those arrow marks that don't go into state G.. And it was 0 for the example in lecture. That's why it's 100*0.5 + 1 =51. Other values are respectively calculated.

followup.name: Mohammadreza Barazesh
followup.text: the immediate rewards in this question are different. r=1 is given for other directions.

followup.name: Chai Zheng Xin
followup.text: Shouldn't the goal state be 100? My answer set G as 100 and iterated other state values accordingly. Or else, the agent will not be incentivised to go to goal state. State values should be designed to affect policy decisions. If goal is 0, then agent will not enter goal.

replies.name: Sriram
replies.text:
If you look at the formula again, it says Max (over all actions) [r(s,a) + gamma*V(next state using action)]
  the goal state has only one action to perform that is to stay in the goal state.
- r(G, "stay") = 0
- next state it goes to using the action is G, whose Value is initially set as 0.
  Thus V*(G) = 0.
Also, the agent will enter the goal because entering it will give the agent 100 reward from either left or from bellow.

title: Explanation of Test 47 for HW3
author: Chai Zheng Xin
text:
Can anyone explain the correct output for test 47 of HW3? 
  Input File:47
2
Schoolmate(Alice,Bob)
Schoolmate(Bob,Alice)
2
((Inschool(x) & Inschool(y)) => Schoolmate(x,y))
Inschool(a)
Correct output:
TRUE
TRUE
  Update: I understood the reasoning so disregard this post.

author: Sriram
student_answer.text:
The CNF for this would be 
1: ~Inschool(x) | ~Inschool(y) | Schoolmate(x,y)
2: Inschool(a)
3: ~Schoolmate(Alice, Bob)
  4: 1+3: ~Inschool(Alice) | ~Inschool(Bob)
5: 4+3: ~Inschool(Bob) {a/Alice}
6: 5+2: [] {a/Bob} - Contradiction
  You can do a similar thing for the next query.

title: inference doubt
author: shashi kiran yellappa (anon. to classmates)
text:
suppose if the negation of the statement that we are trying to prove is A(x,y) & A(a,b) & ~A(c,d). 
we add all three clauses to kb. Can't we take A(x,y) and ~A(c,d) and unify them? this will result in a contradiction. hence conclude that the given query is true, I am not sure where I am going wrong. Could someone please point me in the right direction?

author: Sriram (anon. to classmates)
student_answer.text:
This may not be an answer you are looking for, but it may give you a direction
It depends on the scope of the variables. For instance,
for all a,b,c: A(a, b) ^ A(b, c) ^ ~A(a,c)
this statement is bound and cannot be removed unless we know the values of a,b,c by this I mean that the {a/Constant} in the first predicate is the same as the "a" in the third predicate. the predicates are bounded by the universal instantiation. 
  for the example you have given the variable scopes are limited to the predicate and can be split and inferred as Contradiction.

followup.name: shashi kiran yellappa (anon. to classmates)
followup.text:
Hi, Thanks for the answer. But my doubt is after converting to cnf all the variables are universal. And we can standardize the variables also. So A(a,b) & A(b,c) & ~A(a,c) can be written as 3 statements in kb after standardizing as  :
1. A(a,b)
2. A(c,d)
3. ~A(e,f)
  so now I can take 1 and 3 and proceed right ? where am I going wrong?

replies.name: Sriram
replies.text: You cannot split this statement. Because the variables are in the same scope across different predicates, your conversion should add more statements like b=c, d=e and a=f just to ensure the variables are right.

replies.name: shashi kiran yellappa (anon. to classmates)
replies.text:
Hi,
The resolution algorithm just adds contradiction to kb and picks two sentences and unifies them. It doesn't see anything else. If the two sentences are unifiable they get unified else it picks other pair of sentences and tries again right ? once it is part of the kb how will it matter ti what statement it belongs to?

title: Missing Grade
author: Nitesh Venkatesh
text:
Hi ,
  I do not see my final letter grade on stars report or D2L USC Please confirm if this is a problem or the final grades have not been published yet ?

title: MGs Will Be Fixed
author: Elizabeth Staruk
text:
Students in Tuesday's section will not have their grades released until later. We apologize for any inconvenience.
  (This said 'Monday' before, but we do not know when the updated grades will appear on your record. Most offices are closed until January 3rd.)
  To calculate your final grade:
20% for midterm-1 + 
20% for midterm-2 + 
30% for final + 
30% for homeworks (10% each homework)
    >= 90 A+ (honorary - shows as A on transcript)
>= 80 A
>= 75 A-
>= 70 B+
>= 60 B
>= 55 B-
>= 50 C+
>= 40 C
>= 35 C-
< 35 F
  #pin

followup.name: Sunil Muralidhara (anon. to classmates)
followup.text:
We received this today morning. Let us know if anything we have to from our side.
[FYI]
  Dear Student,
  Our records indicate that you have a missing grade (MG) for your course CSCI-561 in the fall 2016 semester.  Please address all inquiries regarding resolution of this MG to your instructor.  Our office will only be able to correct this MG after the required signed paperwork from your instructor has been received.
  Regards,
  -Jim
  James Feigert, Ed.D.
Assistant Registrar
Academic Records and Registrar | University of Southern California
615 Childs Way, TRO-101 | Los Angeles, CA 90089-0912
Ph: 213-740-9230 | Fax: 213-740-5986 | feigert@usc.edu

replies.text: With all my respect, the fact that university will be closed is predictable and well-known. It is weird to ask the recruiter to take the score-letter mapping and figure my grade. Upset and disappointed.

replies.text: OK. I don't think anyone else is reading this, though.

  Letter Grade 4.0 Scale
A+ 4
A 4
A- 3.7
B+ 3.3
B 3
B- 2.7
C+ 2.3
C 2
C- 1.7
D+ 1.3
D 1
E/F 0
